             <a href="/user/uid:126035">
              Tonga 23
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            If someone showed up in my yard in a confrontational fashion, I'd be deep in my rights to be upset and in my part of the country, express that sense of threat in ways that are not very nice to intruders.
           </p>
           <p>
            A whole lot more of the country is going to be suddenly much more sympathetic to Bill O'Reilly.
           </p>
           <p>
            It's one thing to gotcha George Allen in a public venue.
           </p>
           <p>
            Going to a private resident is way across the line, Mike.
           </p>
           <p>
            We will just have to hope O'Reilly shows his ass again, and soon.
           </p>
           <p>
            But he's too smart for that, is my bet. The outrage is an act; he's going to lay back and we are going to be the ones who are the loons.
           </p>
           <p>
            Today we are all Mike Stark.
           </p>
           <p>
            And that's not a proud feeling right now.
           </p>
          </div>

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:122839">

          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            "don't post it here," well this has always been a user content driven website. Are we going to decide all of a sudden what "looks good" for DKos? That is not what we are about.
           </p>
           <p>
            Mike stays within the law. Mike plays by the rules. Yes, he knows where all the little holes are in those rules, but that is not the point.
           </p>
           <p>
            O'Reilly has stepped way over the bounds when he started trying to shame politicians into ignoring our concerns. O'Reilly took up this fight and has tried to make a mockery of us for weeks.
           </p>
           <p>
            I say, good for you Mike and Fuck O'Reilly. He is a public persona and if he can sling the shit, he can take it.
           </p>

           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             I think the rule in this case is
            </span>

        <li id="c189">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12780123">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            On balance, it's OK
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12780123#c189?mode=alone;showrate=1#c189">
             5+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:18605">
              opinionated
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:68807">
              djbender
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:69938">
              kestrel9000
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:116091">
              Break On Through
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:122839">
              kyril
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            The pluses outweigh the minuses, and the pluses are:
           </p>
           <p>
            1 Sorry, Bill, if the truth hurts, but it's still the truth. If you don't like the truth, you shouldn't have done it.
           </p>
           <p>
            2 The power-challenged are up against a juggernaut. It's necessary to communicate creatively when a multi-million dollar megaphone is unavailable.
           </p>
           <p>
            3 It's consistent with the "do no harm" rule. C'mon, c'mon, c'mon .. . there's no real damage done here.
           </p>
           <p>
            The medium is the message, however, and the medium in this case is too much like that of the opponent. Personally, I wouldn't have done it. But in the final analysis, elections are won by 51% of the vote, and you won the election.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            "When Siddhartha has a goal, he does nothing. He thinks, he waits, he fasts. He goes through life like a stone through water." - H. Hesse, Siddhartha

            but I doubt that O'Reilly will say anything about it publically. He does NOT discuss the harassment case, EVER -- and a good portion of his fans have no idea what happened.
           </p>
           <p>
            I joke about his fans being old, but seriously, Fox has a lot of elderly people convinced that they can't trust anything they hear or read anywhere else -- and they just don't bother trying.
           </p>
           <p>
            Given a choice between keeping that base in the dark and pubically getting back at Mike -- I think he'll keep his base.

         </div>
        </li>
        <li id="c225">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12780246">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Sending BillO Over the Edge
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12780246#c225?mode=alone;showrate=1#c225">
             5+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:18605">
              opinionated
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:25029">
              taonow
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:54433">
              boofdah
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:60572">
              Floja Roja
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:115299">
              AshesAllFallDown
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            On principal I disapprove of this tactic, however I can see turnabout is fair play, especially dealing with a sleazebag like Falafel Bill. Be warned though, I've put myself in a similar situation with a local GOP politician and he came after me with guns blazing (metaphorically speaking). In the end, I regretted my actions, although I came out of it relatively smelling like a rose.
           </p>
           <p>
            My prediction: You can expect BillO to pop a nut on his show tonight. This may put him over the edge.
           </p>
           <p>
            I'm making some Jiffy Pop.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            "Tyranny, like hell, is not easily conquered; yet we have this consolation with us, that the harder the conflict, the more glorious the triumph."
           </p>
           <p class="cb">

         <div class="cx" id="cx12780260">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Usually I'm hypercautious
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12780260#c229?mode=alone;showrate=1#c229">
             15+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">

            <dd>

             </a>

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:35187">

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:56450">

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:67221">

             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:69938">

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:77390">

             </a>

             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:106912">

             </a>

             </a>

             </a>

          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            but I'm not at all uncomfortable with Mike's visit to O'Reilly's home.
            <br/>
            O'Reilly is a public person and I'm sure it's not the first time someone in the press appeared in his neighborhood.
           </p>
           <p>
            O'Reilly is a hatemonger who regularly threatens others and I don't see why a little reciprocal street theater is out of line.
           </p>
           <p>
            When "60 Minutes" or "Dateline" approach their subjects at home is there a hue and cry? Do we cry "foul?" I haven't seen it.
           </p>
           <p>
            Maybe I'm missing something here, but I have only one thing to say to Mike:
            <br/>
            "Thanks!"
           </p>

        <li id="c230">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12780273">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            A distinction that might be important:
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12780273#c230?mode=alone;showrate=1#c230">
             6+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:3930">
              vivacia
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:18605">
              opinionated
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:44069">
              rapala
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:60572">
              Floja Roja
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:69938">
              kestrel9000
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:116091">
              Break On Through
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            I'd be completely against what MS did if the case were different; for example:
           </p>
           <blockquote>
            <p>
             Some one posts a right wing letter to the NY Times; his addressed is found out, signs are put up around his neighborhood, he's confronted in his driveway, etc.
            </p>
           </blockquote>
           <p>
            That really looks bad, imho. But Billo is different, at least as far as I understand the facts. He's used the national airwaves to do confront people at their homes (or at least once to my knowledge). He's in effect endorsed such behavior and encourages it.
           </p>
           <p>
            MS removed some of the privilege and distance that allows Billo to treat people as bits of junk to kick around. It seems to me to place him more on the level of his victims. My biggest concern with it is that it will have no effect.
           </p>
          </div>

             <a href="/user/uid:115299">
              AshesAllFallDown
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <blockquote>
            <p>
             Update [2007-7-31 10:6:59 by Mike Stark]: Wanted to address the naysayers: please take your concern to your own diaries. My opening statement to Bill was that I was providing an accountability moment.
            </p>
           </blockquote>
           <p>
            Take your stupid stunt to your own site - You can report all day long there this kind of crap - but keep it off of Dailykos. All you should have done is write a diary with a link to your site...........But no you think you are cute -
           </p>
           <p>
            Last I checked you look like you are trespassing.... On his driveway and property without permission - that is not cool.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            Turn Virginia Blue  - 2007 21/51

         <li id="c309">
          <div class="cx" id="cx12780460">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Disagree about reporting and being an activist
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/364689/12780460#c309?mode=alone;showrate=1#c309">
              4+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:3189">
               Radiowalla
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:3930">
               vivacia
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:18605">
               opinionated
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:100531">
               ubertar
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             One can be "both", if one admits it up front their bias. And that's the crucial difference. You are confusing what
             <em>
              passes for 'journalism' today
             </em>
             with the 'fair and balanced' meme.
            </p>
            <p>
             The truth is not 'fair and balanced', it's simply the truth. Period.
            </p>
            <p>
             Perhaps, one must out of necessity call Mike a 'muckraker', rather than a 'journalist'. However it does not make his
             <em>
              reporting
             </em>
             any less valid. It just requires that we understand where Mike is coming from.
            </p>
            <p>
             The nice thing about Mike is that he makes no effort to hide behind an American Flag, faux morality or a fake slogan like 'fair and balanced' to do his reporting.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             socialist democratic progressive pragmatic idealist with a small d.

        <li id="c239">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12780295">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Good for the Goose
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12780295#c239?mode=alone;showrate=1#c239">
             8+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:3930">
              vivacia
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:44069">
              rapala
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:60572">
              Floja Roja
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:64990">
              WuChier
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:67221">
              MuffledDrum
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:69938">
              kestrel9000
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:106912">
              MichiganGirl
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:116091">
              Break On Through
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            I don't believe in eye for an eye. I don't believe that two or even three wrongs make a right.
           </p>
           <p>
            But I know that on numerous occasions, Bill O'Reilly has called everybody here, personally, a Nazi. He has also accused us of being just like the KKK. You know, the people who tar, feather, and lynch innocent people.
           </p>
           <p>
            Bill O'Reilly is also a sexual predator.
           </p>
           <p>
            The behavior exhibited towards O'Reilly today wasn't even nearly as trashy as the behavior he regularly lashes out with at you, me, and the CEO of JetBlue.
           </p>
           <p>
            While I personally wouldn't have done this, I don't care in this instance that it was done to him. It was inevitable that somebody would get around to it eventually. Human nature dictates this, and he should know better than to think he can just scream his way through life cutting off everyone else's microphones.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>
           <p class="cb">

            Cindy Sheehan went to Bush's ranch
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12780307#c246?mode=alone;showrate=1#c246">
             17+ / 0-
            </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:120711">

          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Whether or not you thinks she's gone too far since, most everyone thought it was pretty cool that she did what she did by taking it his vacation home. Bill O'Reilly is no more a private citizen than Bush is. He's a public personality, a media fixture who thinks he can say any lie about anyone. Mike Stark is just doing what Cindy Sheehan did. Mike is an "activist" in the true sense of the word, who isn't afraid to ask the tough and challenging questions that we should all be asking of all of our political and media figures. In fact if the journalists were doing their job, O'Reilly would be out of business. Instead O'Reilly is leading them. Mike had a big part in exposing the hypocrasy, lies and bigotry of George Allen. His gorilla brand of accountablity helped to force the media to keep Allen's remarks on the front page. Today we've got Jim Webb, thanks in part to Mike Stark. So take your best shot Mr. O'Reilly. My money's on Mike Stark.
           </p>

             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              There's a big difference between the driveway and
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/364689/12780857#c456?mode=alone;showrate=1#c456">
               1+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:116091">
                Break On Through
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              the domicile. Stepping over the threshold of a doorway is crossing the line. I'm no lawyer, but IIRC being in a driveway is common access, unless it's gated.
             </p>
             <p>
              I don't see a gate. I don't see any forced entry.
             </p>
             <p>
              How many times have you heard or seen stories about regular everday citizens who have the press camping out in their yard when they inadvertently become media personalities?
             </p>
             <p>
              If O'Reilly asked Mike to leave and Mike refused, that would be another kettle of fish. I don't see that being the case here, either.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              socialist democratic progressive pragmatic idealist with a small d.
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:15850">
               shpilk
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/364689/12780857#c456">
               Tue Jul 31, 2007 at 07:52:21 AM PDT
              </a>
             </p>
             <p class="cl">
              [
              <a href="#c379">
               Parent
              </a>
              ]
             </p>
            </div>
           </div>
          </li>
          <li id="c501">
           <div class="cx" id="cx12780979">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Mike's in the Driveway...
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/364689/12780979#c501?mode=alone;showrate=1#c501">
               1+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:96725">
                dclawyer06
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              ...talking to O'Reilly. That's fair game, and walking up someone's driveway for purpose of knocking on the door to talk with the house occupant is appropriate.
             </p>
             <p>
              That's why a driveway is there in the first place.
             </p>
            </div>

        <li id="c257">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12780326">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            What This Reminds Me Of
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12780326#c257?mode=alone;showrate=1#c257">
             4+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:20146">
              cskendrick
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:22311">
              ATL Dem
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:28222">
              sele
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:34397">
              Caldonia
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Back in 1972 the wheelchair-confined George Wallace was campaigning for president in Wisconsin, home state of Arthur Bremer, the man who had shot Wallace, severing his spine. Wallace was campaigning, whipping up white racism and resentment about integration of the public schools and affirmative action. We hated him.
           </p>
           <p>
            When Wallace made his way to Madison, he was greeted by a cadre of Yippies, each wearing an Arthur Bremer mask, and each pushing a wheelchair.
           </p>
           <p>
            Their chant was, "Free Arthur Bremer; Give 'im another chance; He shoulda shot him in the head but he shot him in the pants."
           </p>
           <p>
            At the time, my 17 year-old self thought it was funny. Now not so much.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            This aggression will not stand, man.
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:6868">
             kaleidescope
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/364689/12780326#c257">
             Tue Jul 31, 2007 at 07:24:25 AM PDT
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>

         <ul class="cm i1" id="k12780365">
          <li id="c658">
           <div class="cx" id="cx12781489">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              People who wouldn't slam DKos otherwise
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/364689/12781489#c658?mode=alone;showrate=1#c658">
               3+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:24682">
                lorri
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:28222">
                sele
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:28895">
                revsue
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              will be turned off by someone harrassing a public figure at his home. Saying "It's bad if you do it to good people, but okay if you do it to bad people" is infinitely stupid, as some kind of concept of "due process" applies in life, not only in court.
             </p>
             <p>
              Except in rare and extreme circumstances, for instance where there really is no other way to bring attention to the misdeeds of someone with a lot of power, public discussions should not be transferred to following someone home.
             </p>
             <p>
              Bill O'Reilly putting out distortions and misinformation and attacking DKos is not an extreme circumstance; it's just par for the course. And we have better ways to deal with it -- in the public sphere, where we should be dealing with it.
             </p>
             <p>
              And this is not being "a reporter." Spare me that pretentiousness. When you're putting up signs attacking someone, you're not being a reporter. The goal here was to make O'Reilly feel vulnerable -- at least vulnerable to being harrassed. That's not being a reporter.
             </p>
             <p>
              This was a misguided exercise from start to finish.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:116231">
               Fiona West
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/364689/12781489#c658">

              </a>

              </a>
              ]

            </p>
            <p>
             At
             <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2007/7/30/20019/5784">
              some point
             </a>
             , this plays into his hands.
            </p>
           </div>

              <a href="http://tinyurl.com/2clv33" rel="nofollow">

          <li id="c447">
           <div class="cx" id="cx12780829">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              well, anything he chooses to spin
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/364689/12780829#c447?mode=alone;showrate=1#c447">
               2+ / 0-
              </a>

             </span>

               <a href="/user/uid:106912">

               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>

            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              to those who get all or most of their input from him - he can "use" any way he wants.
             </p>
             <p>
              but it's a new playing field, these days, when someone such as Mike can perform the same type of confrontational action as Billo's minions...
              <em>
               for the purpose of getting publicity
              </em>
              - the type of publicity that only people such as Billo had access to in the past.
             </p>
             <p>
              When anyone reacts negatively to such confrontation, it delivers the question to the public eye:
             </p>
             <p>
              <strong>
               why, then, don't you think it's wrong for B.O. to do this to people?
              </strong>
             </p>

         <li id="c348">
          <div class="cx" id="cx12780557">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Last Summer...
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/364689/12780557#c348?mode=alone;showrate=1#c348">
              5+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:17898">
               alou73
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:21972">
               evilrick
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:27895">
               lirtydies
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:44069">
               rapala
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:96228">
               profmom
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             about 30 anti-abortionists with giant 12-foot high dismembered fetus pictures went to my best friend's house in Raleigh NC. Her name is Susan Hill and they also had a picture of her with "KILLER" on it. She owns the
             <a href="http://www.nwho.com">
              National Women's Health Organization
             </a>
             a group of 5 abortion clinics.
            </p>
            <p>
             They also went around to all her neighbors trying to discredit her and left them a flyer about Susan.
            </p>
            <p>
             Nobody got arrested. Nobody got in trouble.
            </p>
            <p>
             Looks like Mike is just taking a hint from the anti-abortion playbook.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             <a href="http://www.hotflashreport.com" rel="nofollow">

                </p>
                <p>
                 So, if BillO has more connections to get picketing, etc. banned in neighborhoods...then, yes...that will help abortion providers who've been
                 <strong>
                  harassed for years
                 </strong>
                 in their neighborhoods with no repercussions.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Until then, let the fur fly.

           <span class="cu">
            Good or Bad?  Depends on your
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12780566#c352?mode=alone;showrate=1#c352">
             6+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>

          <div class="crs">

            <dt>

          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            understanding of the national political situation.
           </p>
           <p>
            If you believe that politics is a gentlemen's game, and that we can agree to disagree, and when it is all over we can share a drink and a cigar together, then Mike's actions are over the top and an embarrassment.
           </p>
           <p>
            On the other hand, if you believe we are in a constitutional crisis, with a unitary executive attempting to destroy /fundamentally change our constitutional system of government then it is a patriot's duty to defend their country. And as BillO has clearly aligned himself with the unitary executive, what Mike did is not excessive.
           </p>
           <p>
            Myself...i don't know. Depends whether i have my tinfoil hat on or not.
           </p>

           </p>
           <p>
            How else could he put his concerned face on television and his humorless voice on the radio every day and make shit up? All day long?
           </p>
           <p>
            Why do you think he came out of the house and talked to Mike Stark? He gets off on the attention.
           </p>
           <p>
            This accomplished nothing but making him feel that tickly feeling he gets in his lower belly. Like when telling his assistant producer that he will destroy any woman that tries to mess with him. Or like telling her that he thinks, as a woman, she should use a vibrator. He's egomaniac. He knows everything. He's right about everyone. He thinks he's an expert on vaginal stimulation for effen sake!
           </p>
           <p>
            This experiment accomplished one thing for two people. It made the visitor and the visitee feel important to their respective audience. Mike Stark's audience is right here at DailyKos, which is why he posted to tell us about it. And soon O'Reilly's audience will hear about it.
           </p>
           <p>
            This was a commonplace ego fuck.
           </p>

            When you go after them in their own arena -- on the air or on the Web -- I think you do some good things, Mike. But this strikes me as over the line.
           </p>
           <p>
            Worse yet, you've made the story more about him, which is what he wants in the first place.
           </p>
           <p>
            My opinion is you've stooped to his/their level, and unfortunately, this will ultimately help him.
           </p>
          </div>

             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:69938">

             </a>
             ,

             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:90840">
              godislove
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:96174">
              Skamp
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:101902">
              davefromqueens
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:107812">
              roguetrader2000
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:116091">
              Break On Through
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:121041">
              CC Music Factory
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:128690">
              Issek
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            I've always had a wonder on how the rich &amp; powerful keep thousands happily beneath them. Why, I wondered, why don't people stand up for themselves?
           </p>
           <p>
            Now I know.
           </p>
           <p>
            How many times have you seen someone questioned at their front door by your local media? How many times have you seen people sulking to their car trying to
            <strong>
             not
            </strong>
            answer media questions?
           </p>
           <p>
            Where is the outrage for the local news station or national news outlet standing in front of someone's house?
            <br/>
            There's none. They call it journalism.
           </p>
           <p>
            But if it is a few citizens -
            <strong>
             not backed by millions of media money, not backed by a phalanx of lawyers, not comforted by a corrupt corporate media atmosphere
            </strong>
            - who dare attempt the same journalism, you call it stalking?
           </p>
           <p>
            We don't need to worry about the government trying to stop us from enjoying our freedoms -
            <strong>
             we're doing it to ourselves.
            </strong>
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">

             I agree that it is not stalking.  Distributing
            </span>

             <a href="/comments/364689/12780787#c431?mode=alone;showrate=1#c431">

           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             the court transcripts to the neighbors is legitimate IMHO because these are legal court documents that arose from a suit brought against O'Reilly by a victim of his. It's not as though Mike blanketed the neighbors with O'Reilly's private correspondence or diary entries. The stuff he distributed to the neighbors is PUBLIC RECORD. It's true it is aggressive to go to the man's residence and post a "pervert" sign at his driveway entrance. But it is not illegal and it is not done without there being a legal judgement against O'Reilly that provides a basis for the "pervert" sign.
            </p>

         <li id="c483">
          <div class="cx" id="cx12780934">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             There's a proper time and place for everything
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/364689/12780934#c483?mode=alone;showrate=1#c483">
              1+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:5593">
               4democracy
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             Confronting someone in their driveway as they get the paper is an extreme measure.
            </p>
            <p>
             I don't like it when the media does it, but there are times when it is the only way to reach a person who has questions that ought to be answered. THAT'S NOT THE CASE HERE. If you want to ask O'Reilly pointed questions, he is a publicly available figure.
            </p>
            <p>
             Secondarily, the media (well, at least most of the media) have traditional standards and defined boundaries that regulate their actions. When you're confronted by an individual in your driveway like this, there's no understanding of those ground rules.
            </p>
            <p>
             There are appropriate venues for protesting against Bill O'Reilly. This kind of guerrilla action in his own front yard is not on that list.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">

            <div class="ct">
             <blockquote>
              <p>
               If you want to ask O'Reilly pointed questions, he is a publicly available figure.
              </p>
             </blockquote>
             <p>
              You are talking about the man who cuts off the microphone of people on his own show - and you suggest he'll be publicly available somewhere else?
              <br/>
              Yeah, right.
             </p>
             <blockquote>
              <p>
               Secondarily, the media (well, at least most of the media) have traditional standards and defined boundaries that regulate their actions. When you're confronted by an individual in your driveway like this, there's no understanding of those ground rules.
              </p>
             </blockquote>
             <p>
              Are you suggesting that the media conducts itself in ways that private citizens cannot? Or are the ground rules of civil society magically forgotten if someone
              <strong>
               doesn't
              </strong>
              have a press badge and asks you a question?
             </p>
             <p>
              Mike will not have follow-up opportunities to rebut what BillO does next, and laid out exactly what he should expect if he continues his assault on private citizens. Mike is as much a journalist as is BillO.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              "I'm not an actor, but I play one on TV."
             </p>

         <li id="c506">
          <div class="cx" id="cx12780986">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             this is not jounalism
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/364689/12780986#c506?mode=alone;showrate=1#c506">
              10+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:5593">
               4democracy
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:28054">
               celticshel
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:28895">
               revsue
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:32856">
               QuestionableSanity
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:62295">
               Ekaterin
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:64115">
               Over the Edge
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:69254">
               Absit invidia
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:78311">
               vox humana
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:79710">
               poppyseed
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:110850">
               AJsMom
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             It is one thing to show up and ask Bill questions and give him an accountability moment. Frankly, it would have been smart to mimick the discussion that he had with the CEO of jetBlue.
            </p>
            <p>
             But how people can say that this is "just like when journalists show up at someone's house to ambush them," I can't wrap my head around.
            </p>
            <p>
             Reporters may be sleazy, vile, and agenda driven, but the good ones have the uncanny ability to frame everything they ask as a "serious question." Yes, I mean that in the Atrios way of "serious."
            </p>
            <p>
             There is nothing wrong with asking questions.
            </p>
            <p>
             But showing up at someone's house with a loofa and mocking signs about his legal situation is not an accountability moment. It's encouraging a multi-millionare egomaniac with a microphone and a camera pointed in his direction every day to continue to believe the world revolves around his opinions.
            </p>
            <p>
             You can be "ballsy" or you can be "smart" or you can be both.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
            </p>

        <li id="c370">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12780620">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Is a recalibration needed?
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12780620#c370?mode=alone;showrate=1#c370">
             2+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:75492">
              Dauphin
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:92864">
              Positronicus
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            O'Reilly isn't going after this website. He's going after the Democratic candidates by pointing out that they've abandoned the DLC, but will be attending YearlyKos. If he can succeed in painting this website as "extreme left", and in relation to the right-wing DLC that's not so hard to do, then he can support the new media narrative that "the Democratic party is moving left."
           </p>
           <p>
            Rather than fighting on his terms, we should be asking "what's wrong with 'moving left'?" It's not going to be easy for BillO and the DLC to show a lot of benefit from the last 6 or 7 years of "moving right", is it?
           </p>
           <p>
            IMO, many of you are fighting the wrong fight.
           </p>
           <p>
            (This is
            <strong>
             NOT
            </strong>
            a shot at Mike, who has the same first amendment rights that everyone else has. BillO is repulsive, although his neighbors probably already know that better than most.)
           </p>
          </div>

          <div class="cf">

        <li id="c392">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12780686">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            with all due respect
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12780686#c392?mode=alone;showrate=1#c392">
             14+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:319">

             </a>
             ,

             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:5593">
              4democracy
             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:31985">

             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:34397">
              Caldonia
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:41533">
              realalaskan
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:48649">
              goffnews
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:64926">
              concordepa
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:69254">
              Absit invidia
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:79710">
              poppyseed
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:105233">
              echohotel330
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:116941">
              Same As It Ever Was
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:125880">
              Garden Neighbor
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            but telling "naysayers" to take it to their own diaries is uncool.
           </p>
           <p>
            If you post a diary, you have to expect that people who don't agree with your argument or position or activities will post their opinion.
           </p>
           <p>
            It's part of the risk of posting a diary.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            <i>
             <a href="http://blogatha.blogspot.com/" rel="nofollow">
              Blogatha!
             </a>

           <p class="cb">

        </li>
        <li id="c402">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12780718">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Empathy workshops are the answer
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12780718#c402?mode=alone;showrate=1#c402">
             16+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:630">
              claude
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:3930">
              vivacia
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:5098">
              AaronInSanDiego
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:9197">
              Hounds
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:13275">
              AWhitneyBrown
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:17898">
              alou73
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:21972">
              evilrick
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:22096">
              Loquatrix
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:28022">
              rocketito
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:35215">
              DSC on the Plateau
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:42316">
              pontechango
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:42949">
              Sol Fed Joe
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:52090">
              ThunderHawk13
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:63264">
              viscerality
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:90840">
              godislove
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:116091">
              Break On Through
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Mike,
           </p>
           <p>
            Non-violently confronting someone like Bill O'Reilly to point out his hypocrasy isn't the way to go.
           </p>
           <p>
            No. What's needed is a workshop so that we can all get in touch with our feelings and stuff and junk. Maybe we can visualize Bill surrounded in our healing world-aura.
           </p>
           <p>
            We have to rise above the O'Reilly types. I say, let them continue to lie, badmouth and threaten those they disagree with. I think those who don't cherish and value what Bill has to contribute to the public screaming match that used to be a forum for discussion and thought should accept that they need to shut up, sit down, and accept all the shit that's being rammed down their throats.
           </p>
           <p>
            That's right. Keep smiling through a mouthful as one by one every civil right is taken away. Spy cameras everywhere because, well, only the guilty have something to hide. Of course, George W. Bush hiding everything he can find, including e-mails, that's not deception, that's him protecting his privacy and that of his family from the folks who aren't holding America's interests first.
           </p>
           <p>
            Mike. The only legitimate complaint I've got is that you didn't get better-looking signage. Kinko's could have made some nice weatherproof ones for you in a couple of hours.
           </p>
           <p>
            And for all the morons -- yes, I call you morons because you are apparently too stupid to incorporate the last six years of experience into a viable worldview -- who are hyperventilating because someone decided to non-violently confront Bill O'Reilly's hypocrasy, why don't you wake the fuck up? Either wake up or get a caretaker because Jesus down from the cross, you can't/shouldn't/mustn't be left alone.
           </p>
           <p>
            I always used to wonder how so many incredibly intelligent people got caught by the Nazis. "Oh, we didn't think Hitler would come to power. Oh, we didn't think he'd come for the German Jews. Oh, we didn't think the camps were for real. Oh, the tattoos are just for identification. Oh, I'll get my stuff back when I leave the showers -- see, they gave me a receipt."
           </p>
           <p>
            Wake up already you dumbasses. For Christ's sweet sake, please stop doing pastels about your emotional well-being. You don't debate a tidal wave, you don't attempt a consensus-building session when a gang starts wailing on your head.
           </p>
           <p>
            You're like the reverse of a panicking crowd. When you should be doing something, you just mill around being ineffectual AND THEN have the "Oh-let-me-stick-my-dick-in-the-light-socket" mentality to criticize someone who is engaging in a brilliant piece of NOT INTIMIDATION but CONFRONTATION.
           </p>
           <p>
            That's what adults do. They CONFRONT problems. They don't run away from them. They don't piss and moan about them (well, they piss and moan about them, but then they CONFRONT them). They don't wait for someone else to do it.
           </p>
           <p>
            Did Mike do a single violent thing? No. He did not. Did he get a single fact wrong? No. He did not.
           </p>
           <p>
            He finally had enough of O'Reilly cramming turd after turd down the gullets of America, stood up and said that he's had enough of this shit.
           </p>
           <p>
            God Almighty. Does anyone here actually live in the reality-based world?
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:125417">
             Alex With an E
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/364689/12780718#c402">
             Tue Jul 31, 2007 at 07:45:00 AM PDT
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>

          <div class="ct">
           <p>

           </p>
           <p>

Why is it suddenly offsides the second it's aimed at Bill O'Reilly? Because he might say something bad about Daily Kos on TV? Well that ship sailed a long time ago, and IMHO it's a pointless thing to worry about.
           </p>

          <li id="c1028">
           <div class="cx" id="cx12784140">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              If I had the stature to attract national
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/364689/12784140#c1028?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1028">
               2+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:63264">
                viscerality
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:90840">
                godislove
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              media I would be subject to the same exposure as any other celebrity or national persona. That's just a reality I accept.
             </p>
             <p>
              What do you mean by "now?"
              <br/>
              It's pretty standard practice for papparazzi, tabloids news outlets, faux news outlets, and every type and form of media to expose anything and everything of public interest about celebrities. This is nothing. I think any lawful, honest, means to expose this scumbag oreilly for what he is is appropriate and called for.
             </p>
             <p>
              I don't think Mike broke the law, I was responding to the suggestion that he might be taken to court by oreilly by other comments.
             </p>
             <p>
              If he did in fact break the law, or lie, it's not fair game, imo.
             </p>
             <p>
              Unlike bill o, my actions do not invite media scrutiny and critisism of my life, lawful or not, that's just the way it is.
             </p>
            </div>

             </a>

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:103503">

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:107917">

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:111341">

             </a>

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:121222">

             </a>

             </a>

          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            ... upsets and depresses me.
           </p>
           <p>
            I just sat at dinner last night with 10 or so moderate Democrats - we all worked on the Kerry campaign in 2006, and are once again rebanding to do the hard work of pounding the pavement in a 55% Republican precinct.
           </p>
           <p>
            Our conversation focused on how unhinged and unfocused the Right has become; how they have resorted to cheap shots and seem driven by a sense of desperation.
           </p>
           <p>
            I spoke at length about DKos; how I have enjoyed reading the diaries here, and how the "far left hate site" business is total bullshit. I asked my dinner guests to look at the site today, to read the rec'd diaries and see the depth of commitment and vision on this site.
           </p>
           <p>
            Now, I'm really sorry I said that.
           </p>

            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>

              Ever walked through a clinic protest?
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/364689/12781408#c635?mode=alone;showrate=1#c635">
               5+ / 0-
              </a>

             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">

            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              THAT is hate, my friend. Pure, invasive, unadulturated hate.
             </p>
             <p>
              And it is a tactic of the Right - to hit people when they're most vulnerable. In the doorway of a clinic. In their driveways.
             </p>
             <p>
              It would not be a tactic of the progressives I most admire - Martin Luther King, Nelson Mandela, Ghandi.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:119034">
               MyOwnClone
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/364689/12781408#c635">

            </div>
           </div>
          </li>
          <ul class="cm i1" id="k12781408">
           <li id="c675">
            <div class="cx" id="cx12781543">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               Read King's words for yourself
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/364689/12781543#c675?mode=alone;showrate=1#c675">
                7+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:4828">
                 XOVER
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:63264">
                 viscerality
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:65790">
                 esquimaux
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:90222">
                 Nab
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:101902">
                 davefromqueens
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:104129">
                 rrheard
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:106912">
                 MichiganGirl
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <blockquote>
               <p>
                You may well ask: "Why direct action? Why sit-ins, marches and so forth? Isn't negotiation a better path?" You are quite right in calling, for negotiation. Indeed, this is the very purpose of direct action.
                <strong>
                 Nonviolent direct action seeks to create such a crisis and foster such a tension that a community which has constantly refused to negotiate is forced to confront the issue.
                </strong>
                It seeks so to dramatize the issue that it can no longer be ignored. My citing the creation of tension as part of the work of the nonviolent-resister may sound rather shocking. But I must confess that I am not afraid of the word "tension." I have earnestly opposed violent tension, but there is a type of constructive, nonviolent tension which is necessary for growth. Just as Socrates felt that it was necessary to create a tension in the mind so that individuals could rise from the bondage of myths and half-truths to the unfettered realm of creative analysis and objective appraisal, we must we see the need for nonviolent gadflies to create the kind of tension in society that will help men rise from the dark depths of prejudice and racism to the majestic heights of understanding and brotherhood.
               </p>
              </blockquote>
              <p>
               Personally, I think Stark is following this tradition. This action was not violent, hateful, or even illegal. The figures you cite faced the same criticisms of impropriety that Stark is facing.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               <i>
                Essential funk: 'Indictment' by
                <a href="http://www.antibalas.com" rel="nofollow">
                 Antibalas
                </a>
               </i>
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:42316">
                pontechango
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/364689/12781543#c675">

               </a>
              </p>
              <p class="cl">
               [
               <a href="#c635">
                Parent
               </a>
               ]
              </p>
             </div>

               </p>
               <p>
                But my point is that we aren't electing a single damn Democrat by stooping to the level of the Right Wing.
               </p>
               <p>
                And, I maintain, that if King had posted "pervert" signs in Hoover's neighborhood (suspending all disbelief at this point) - he would have accomplished not a damn thing.
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
               </p>
               <p class="cb">

          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            I read the story. I read the updates and explanations. I'm still not convinced.
           </p>
           <p>
            There is confrontation, and then there is
            <em>
             escalation
            </em>
            . Who will be won over by this action? It just seems like further justification on both sides to engage in this tactic, certain of the righteousness of their cause.
           </p>
           <p>
            I appreciate the motivation, but not the action, and I hope you will read the objections of others carefully when you may not feel attacked by them.
           </p>
           <p>
            In sincere appreciation for so many other things you have done,
           </p>

         <ul class="cm i1" id="k12781675">
          <li id="c1242">
           <div class="cx" id="cx12788084">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Sorry for the lateness in seeing your post.
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/364689/12788084#c1242?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1242">
               1+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:2563">
                MissLaura
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              Of course, civility is not the point of my comment at all. My comment is whether the validation of these tactics on both sides lowers the conversation all the way around.
             </p>
             <p>
              When there is no difference in tactics between two sides, it gets harder and harder for those who have not taken a side to care about either. "They're all the same, right? Why should I care?"
             </p>
             <p>
              This kind of action is preaching to the choir, as are the actions of those on the other side. Who is going to see this and suddenly have the veil lifted from their eyes? I submit it changes no minds, only the "playing field."
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              The law is slacked and judgment doth never go forth: the wicked compass about the righteous and wrong judgment proceedeth - Habakkuk 1:4
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:78311">

              </a>

          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            sorry, mr. stark, had you just "reported" as you claim to do (confronted billo with tough questions at his home) i could support this.
           </p>
           <p>
            but the posting of signs takes it out of the realm of reporting and into a subjective attack. it doesn't matter if the signs are true. that's not "reporting" or any semblance of journalism.
           </p>
           <p>
            personally, i'd be surprised if you didn't see a lawsuit out of this. and possibly a restraining order, this is basically unhinged and not the way we should operate. you've just dropped to billo's level.
           </p>
           <p>
            i think dailykos would be wise to distance themselves from this act immediately.

        <li id="c549">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12781099">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Sorry. This is not "reporting".
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12781099#c549?mode=alone;showrate=1#c549">
             9+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:5098">
              AaronInSanDiego
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:6011">
              DelRPCV
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:28895">
              revsue
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:44913">
              Troubled
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:64115">
              Over the Edge
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:64649">
              davisj
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:78311">
              vox humana
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:112640">
              Unbill
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:116231">
              Fiona West
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <blockquote>
            <p>
             And this wasn't stalking. It was reporting.
            </p>
           </blockquote>
           <p>
            Reporting is getting the story. Given O'Reilly's tactics, I don't have a huge problem with "ambushing" O'Reilly at his house to confront him with issues and get the story. But putting up posters around his neighborhood and distributing papers to his neighbors is
            <strong>
             NOT
            </strong>
            reporting.
           </p>
           <p>
            Our national media sucks, and bloggers are making an excellent case to the public for an alternative. BUT THIS IS NOT IT. This is a major step in the wrong direction for DailyKos. It strikes at the heart of legitimacy of bloggers calling themselves journalists, when getting the story becomes making the story in such a tawdry way.
           </p>
           <p>
            If you'd simply interviewed O'Reilly, I would support this as journalism. If you'd pulled the same stunt and simply posted it on your own site, I would accept it as stunt PR. But calling this journalism and posting it on Dkos is damning. It should be pulled.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:74546">
             Scribb
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/364689/12781099#c549">
             Tue Jul 31, 2007 at 08:04:33 AM PDT
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <li id="c553">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12781110">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Appalled and Amused
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12781110#c553?mode=alone;showrate=1#c553">
             6+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:3930">
              vivacia
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:4828">
              XOVER
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:52090">
              ThunderHawk13
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:79887">
              MarketTrustee
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:85179">
              AmericanRiverCanyon
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:97760">
              Ninepatch
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Appalled: "this makes
            <em>
             us
            </em>
            look bad."
           </p>
           <p>
            Whaaat? This I do not get. Mike took it upon himself to investigate and report. He shared it in a diary that bears his name and contact info. He doesn't represent anyone but himself. I look forward to another frothing fit of smearing from the Fear Factor, further underscoring the irony of the hosts' actions and words.
           </p>
           <p>
            Amused: Mike's effort is
            <strong>
             completely
            </strong>
            appropriate. O'Reilly, Fox, and its minions thrive on conflict, confrontation and in-your-face discourse - it is the language and posture of the entire war wing of the right. "Just because they do it doesn't mean we should do it" is a weak response to an effective strategy. Speaking knowledgeably, politely and with decorum has no value for folk like O'Reilly or the war wing. If O'Reilly went back into his kitchen and his coffee that morning with any lesson, its that you reap what you sow. Mike is simply using the same farming tactics. I don't condone this as a permanent way of conducting investigation and reporting (I happen to like knowledgeable sources and decorum), but for this subject its brilliant. And no addresses - I haven't a clue where Bill-O lives, except that it appears as a nice tree-lined street somewhere in NY state. Contrast
            <strong>
             that
            </strong>
            with the war wings' policy and previous actions.
           </p>
          </div>

           <div class="ct">
            <blockquote>
             <p>
              O'Reilly, Fox, and its minions
              <strong>
               thrive
              </strong>
              on conflict, confrontation and in-your-face discourse - it is the language and posture of the entire war wing of the right.
             </p>
            </blockquote>
            <p>
             So, you think we should help them thrive??
            </p>
            <p>
             Immature, childish pranks like these are exactly the kind of ammunition that they wanted...to thrive, in your words....and I for one believe that this community should rise above crap like this, not condone &amp; mimic it.
            </p>
            <p>
             The Progressive blogger movement just took a big step back!!
            </p>
            <p>
             Futile frat-boy pranks like this are the type of actions that will drag DKos down to the same level of the hate-mongers that we are defending ourselves from....this is akin to the "Fight them over there so we don't have to fight them here" strategy! How about forcing them to rise to our level, an intelligent debate level, rather than sinking into their pit of smears &amp; bully-tactics.
            </p>

        <li id="c555">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12781121">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Response to Naysayers - Bill O in Bill O's World
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12781121#c555?mode=alone;showrate=1#c555">
             14+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:3930">
              vivacia
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:4828">
              XOVER
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:17639">
              JLFinch
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:28022">
              rocketito
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:42949">
              Sol Fed Joe
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:44633">
              GuyFromOhio
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:52090">
              ThunderHawk13
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:65790">
              esquimaux
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:86626">
              dotdot
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:90840">
              godislove
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:93802">
              0wn
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:97760">
              Ninepatch
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:112421">
              wyvern
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:129903">
              AnonymousCoward
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            I've read enough, and seen enough, where Bill O. has sent his henchmen into Vermont, and into Colorado (just to name a couple),
            <br/>
            for an 'interview'.
            <br/>
            Bill O. has NEVER considered any personal lines, in pursuit of HIS search for the 'truth' (ha!). Given Bill's resume, this is not a suprise.
            <br/>
            And the more I learn of Bill's childlike, bully tactics (i.e.-his chair's higher than the guest, cutting off mike's, etc.), the clearer I'm convinced Bill's not 'like' a bully...he IS a bully.
            <br/>
            So...how do you handle a bully?
            <br/>
            I think Mike came up with the answer;
            <br/>
            make them live in the world that they've previously dished out.
            <br/>
            As a Kossack, I couldn't be prouder of Mike.
           </p>
          </div>

          <li id="c662">
           <div class="cx" id="cx12781502">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              That's not what Aynsley wrote
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/364689/12781502#c662?mode=alone;showrate=1#c662">
               1+ / 0-
              </a>

            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:65790">
                esquimaux
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              He wrote,
              <em>
               "So...how do you handle a bully?"
              </em>
             </p>
             <p>
              This doesn't 'perpetuate' anything. Its giving right back to the source what the source condones to the world on a widely known cable program. If Mike did this with every topic or subject, then yes, it would be perpetuating "Bill's World." But confronting the very source of such tactics doesn't perpetuate anything, even while underscoring the irony of such tactics. It does make a heck of a story, however.
             </p>
             <p>
              Have you ever had to confront a bully, face to face, one on one? The one thing you
              <strong>
               cannot do
              </strong>
              is back down, otherwise you are a target for all time. Even a bully can learn.
             </p>
            </div>

           <div class="ct">

            </p>

             to respond to someone's baseless attacks is one thing, to adopt their own underhanded tactics is clearly another. and it does, in fact, bring us down to their level.
            </p>
            <p>
             and to adopt a tactic that has been only spoken and not actually undertaken is going beyond their level. can you name one instance when billo has gone to someone's home and confronted them in this manner? if so, please mention it. i don't follow him that closely (he's just trying to agitate and i'll have no part in it) so i'm not aware of it ever happening.
            </p>

             </a>

             </span>
