         <li id="c709">
          <div class="cx" id="cx12781672">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Reminds me of King's letter to his fellow clergy
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/364689/12781672#c709?mode=alone;showrate=1#c709">
              6+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:21590">
               bedobe
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:28022">
               rocketito
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:63264">
               viscerality
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:65790">
               esquimaux
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:90840">
               godislove
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:93802">
               0wn
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             <a href="http://www.nobelprizes.com/nobel/peace/MLK-jail.html">
              http://www.nobelprizes.com/...
             </a>
            </p>
            <blockquote>
             <p>
              While confined here in the Birmingham city jail, I came across your recent statement calling my present activities "unwise and untimely." Seldom do I pause to answer criticism of my work and ideas. If I sought to answer all the criticisms that cross my desk, my secretaries would have little time for anything other than such correspondence in the course of the day, and I would have no time for constructive work. But since I feel that you are men of genuine good will and that your criticisms are sincerely set forth, I want to try to answer your statements in what I hope will be patient and reasonable terms.
             </p>
             <p>
              ...
             </p>
             <p>
              You may well ask: "Why direct action? Why sit-ins, marches and so forth? Isn't negotiation a better path?" You are quite right in calling, for negotiation. Indeed, this is the very purpose of direct action. Nonviolent direct action seeks to create such a crisis and foster such a tension that a community which has constantly refused to negotiate is forced to confront the issue. It seeks so to dramatize the issue that it can no longer be ignored. My citing the creation of tension as part of the work of the nonviolent-resister may sound rather shocking. But I must confess that I am not afraid of the word "tension." I have earnestly opposed violent tension, but there is a type of constructive, nonviolent tension which is necessary for growth. Just as Socrates felt that it was necessary to create a tension in the mind so that individuals could rise from the bondage of myths and half-truths to the unfettered realm of creative analysis and objective appraisal, we must we see the need for nonviolent gadflies to create the kind of tension in society that will help men rise from the dark depths of prejudice and racism to the majestic heights of understanding and brotherhood.
             </p>
            </blockquote>
            <p>
             The fact is, Bill O'Reilly's bullying and demagoguery needs to be confronted non-violently but forcefully. It is time that we brought the unchallenged reign of lies and authoritarianism to an end.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             <i>
              Essential funk: 'Indictment' by
              <a href="http://www.antibalas.com" rel="nofollow">
               Antibalas
              </a>
             </i>
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:42316">
              pontechango
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/364689/12781672#c709">
              Tue Jul 31, 2007 at 08:28:14 AM PDT
             </a>
            </p>

             <a href="#c602">
              Parent
             </a>

            </p>

I don't think it's wrong to cite King's words on direct action in this case.

                <li id="c1066">
                 <div class="cx" id="cx12784619">
                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    alas, i am not wrong, it had nothing to do with
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/364689/12784619#c1066?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1066">
                     0+ / 0-
                    </a>
                    )
                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    Fox News pal.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    The media veered right because they thought in a post 9/11 world that being too anti-Bush would be bad business. It had nothing to do with pressure from Fox, which had existed for years before 9/11, yet had no noticeable impact on other networks news coverage.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    9/11 is obviously the catalyst in the 'de-balling' of the media, not the advent of Fox News.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    We are in Iraq because Bush and his cronies wanted to invade half a decade before we did. O'Reilly just started parroting the talking points in '02. The rest of the media, the mob mentality of the public at the time, the Bush administration and the caving of Senate Democrats are far greater reasons for this war than a single right-wing talking head calling for it.
                   </p>
                  </div>

                     <a href="/comments/364689/12784903#c1089">

                     </a>
                    </p>

                     [
                     <a href="#c1066">

                 <ul class="cm i1" id="k12784903">
                  <li id="c1099">
                   <div class="cx" id="cx12785020">
                    <h5>
                     <a class="de">
                     </a>
                     <span class="cu">
                      how many people watch Fox news at one time?
                     </span>
                     <span class="crd ntb">
                      (
                      <a href="/comments/364689/12785020#c1099?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1099">
                       0+ / 0-
                      </a>
                      )
                     </span>
                    </h5>
                    <div class="ct">
                     <p>
                      4 million, max.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      The war was neither thought up by, or caused, by Fox News. Fox News certainly helped grease the wheels, I won't deny that, but this war was going down with or without the support of Bill O'Reilly, Hannity, etc.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                    <div class="cf">
                     <p class="sig">
                      Barack Obama '08: Because a Generation's Faith in Government Depends On It.
http://gudemocrats.blogspot.com/    Georgetown University Democrats Blog
                     </p>
                     <p class="cb">
                      by
                      <a href="/user/uid:5795">
                       klugerEsel5
                      </a>
                      on
                      <a href="/comments/364689/12785020#c1099">
                       Tue Jul 31, 2007 at 10:38:21 AM PDT
                      </a>
                     </p>
                     <p class="cl">
                      [
                      <a href="#c1089">
                       Parent
                      </a>
                      ]
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>
                  <ul class="cm i1" id="k12785020">
                   <li id="c1146">
                    <div class="cx" id="cx12785862">
                     <h5>
                      <a class="de">
                      </a>
                      <span class="cu">
                       "the most powerful television news organization"
                      </span>
                      <span class="crd ntb">
                       (
                       <a href="/comments/364689/12785862#c1146?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1146">
                        0+ / 0-
                       </a>
                       )
                      </span>
                     </h5>
                     <div class="ct">
                      <p>
                       <a href="http://www.ksg.harvard.edu/news/opeds/2002/jones_fox_mainstream_nyt_120202.htm">
                        http://www.ksg.harvard.edu/...
                       </a>
                      </p>
                      <blockquote>
                       <p>
                        While the total viewership of the three major network nightly news programs dwarfs that of the cable news channels, a more important statistic may well be that
                        <strong>
                         cable news is now a leading source of news for over half the country
                        </strong>
                        , followed by newspapers and local television. Network TV news was ranked fourth, in a survey conducted in January by the Pew Research Center.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        And if cable news is now the nation's main news source, Fox  the self-described maverick outsider  finds itself in the peculiar position of being,
                        <strong>
                         arguably, the most powerful television news organization in the country
                        </strong>
                        , playing a major role in defining what is important and what is not.
                       </p>
                      </blockquote>
                     </div>
                     <div class="cf">
                      <p class="sig">
                       <i>
                        Essential funk: 'Indictment' by
                        <a href="http://www.antibalas.com" rel="nofollow">
                         Antibalas
                        </a>
                       </i>

             </a>

             </a>

          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            .... especially coming from me.
           </p>
           <p>
            But as a person who really has been severely harassed by a real life wing nut vendetta which caused very bad things to happen to me years ago, including tresspassing, attempted intimidation, threats of violence, actual violence, actual stalking, and property destruction, and wherein almost every single friend I thought I had was
            <strong>
             was too cowardly to support me,
            </strong>
            , and we won't even get into the horrific parts involving what the law enforcement did with the media aspect, there is a part of me that is saying,
            <strong>
             At Least Mike Stark is On My Side.
            </strong>
           </p>
           <p>
            Because 99.9% of the time, the person getting the real life harrassment does not get any cooperation nor help from anybody.
           </p>
           <p>
            The pragmatic part of me is saying, well, Mike is going to catch a real shitstorm for this. Another part of me is saying, I sure as hell wouldn't do that. And the third part of me is practically weeping with joy that someone had the courage to do what O Reilly's neighbors will not ever do... perform a community shunning.
            <br/>
            The fourth part is laughing like crazy at the loofah mittens.
           </p>
           <p>
            As I said, while I wouldn't do it, I understand fully the sentiment behind it, and I also understand why people whom have never had this sort of real life harrassment thing happen to them don't "get it." Because they can't imagine anything bad happening to them. If it happened to someone they knew, they'd just... look the other way. Mike Stark is not "looking the other way."
           </p>
           <p>
            I'm glad the diary is here because at least when the shitstorm hits we know what caused it. Sigh.
           </p>

            </span>

         <li id="c1201">
          <div class="cx" id="cx12787183">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Shielding victims of employment discrimination?
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/364689/12787183#c1201?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1201">
              0+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             Catch a clue. Ms. Mackris was willing to state in a public document (a complaint) as part of a tort suit which has been posted all over the internet for years and your concerned about shielding her identity? From what? From people knowing that she achieved a settlement? From the fact that BillO, Westwood, and FNC were so concerned about the merits of the suit that they agreed to settle rather than litigation? Either way catch a clue. Ms. Mackris doesn't need any protecting in the same way a rape victim does. Apples and oranges for those non discriminating hand wringers here.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             At his best, man is the noblest of all animals; separated from law and justice he is the worst.  Aristotle

          <li id="c1252">
           <div class="cx" id="cx12788293">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Shielding her from possible further turmoil.
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/364689/12788293#c1252?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1252">
               0+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              Listen, this has nothing to do with protecting her identity, but rather keeping her name out of the fight between the two machos Mike Stark and Bill O. She lost her privacy due to Bill O's harassment. I am sure that a lot of people had already forgotten her name. Now dKos (and Crooks and Liars) are recycling her to attack Bill O. It is like they are using her.
             </p>
             <p>
              Stark was not letting the world know that their was a settlement in the case, but rather pulling a stunt against Bill O.
             </p>
             <p>
              From my perspective, blasting Bill O could have been done without gratuitously repeating her name, and to let her to return to private life if she so chooses.
             </p>
             <p>
              As for your argument that she brought the publicity upon herself by filing a lawsuit. You are possibly right, she could have let Bill O get away with it. Then at least she could have rest assured that her name wouldn't be plastered on one of the most popular blogs in the country.
             </p>
             <p>
              M*** may not need "protection" as does a rape victim, but we should be more civil when dealing with people who were forced into public life like her. That is what I mean by shielding.

Oh yeah, that's worth it. Not. I'm so sick of the bitterness and the anger and the hatred on both sides that I'm ready to wash my hands of both parties, never vote again, and turn off the goddamn television and the computer.             Let me throw out another line of discussion . . .
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12781858#c749?mode=alone;showrate=1#c749">
             1+ / 0-

             <a href="/user/uid:90840">
              godislove
             </a>

           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            An interesting morning and lively discussion to say the least.
           </p>
           <p>
            To go another direction with this discussion, I'll refer to a
            <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/comments/2007/7/21/151215/370/136#c136">
             comment
            </a>
            I made previously under
            <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2007/7/21/151215/370">
             What makes 'em tick?
            </a>
            Nobody read the comment, but I think it really applies here as well.
           </p>
           <p>
            In short, the DKos community could really benefit from reading and understanding
            <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiral_Dynamics">
             Spiral Dynamics
            </a>
            . The discussion we have here today is a perfect example of the Blue and Green Memes going at each other.
           </p>
           <p>
            I'm not saying this theory is the end-all-be-all, I'm just saying that understanding the basics would give us a better perspective and perhaps a few new tools.
           </p>
           <p>
           </p>

          <li id="c990">
           <div class="cx" id="cx12783786">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Mike Stark's "Breach of Etiquette!"
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/364689/12783786#c990?mode=alone;showrate=1#c990">
               6+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:2312">
                jps
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:18605">
                opinionated
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:90840">
                godislove
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:102176">
                Oreo
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:104129">
                rrheard
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:115655">
                SMWalt
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              Clearly younger DKos "concern trolls" don't have a clue about what happened during the 60's. And, let me just tell you that those students at Kent State weren't doing anything to justify the Guard being called out either to shoot them down like dogs either!
             </p>
             <p>
              But, of course, people like Billo don't care whether their oppression and attacks of you are justified. In their sick minds, they have the right to oppress you, slander you and libel you just because you don't think the way they do.
             </p>
             <p>
              To the "kinder, gentler" concern trolls here at Kos, STARK's accountability moment is a shocking breach of etiquette!!
             </p>
             <p>
              Well.... for those who weren't there to cover the Pentagon and Capitol steps in horse manure, or burn down Watts, or get into shoot-outs with agents in defense of the American Indian Movement, or occupy administrative offices and shut down classes at Berkeley, or, as things evolved, take people hostage or become anarchists or revolutionaries like CHE or Students for a Democratic Society or the Weathermen, it's really just "too much!" They want a "revolution" without have to do all that "hard work!"
             </p>
             <p>
              Jeez. They think Mike Stark is harsh for putting up a few signs and distributing the text of a court case against Billo.
             </p>
             <p>
              It pales in comparison. No wonder we can't end this fucking war.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
             </p>

          <li id="c1316">
           <div class="cx" id="cx12789484">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              No he doesn't
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/364689/12789484#c1316?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1316">
               0+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              We can not quit because you disagree with the tactics used here (as do I).
             </p>
             <p>
              If this is the first time you have felt this, you haven't been here long enough. It happens. In cycles.
             </p>
             <p>
              When the shit-flinging gets so bad I have a hard time seeing us all behave like bored chimps with anger management issues--I take a couple of days off or don't click on diaries I know everyone in it will be covered with feces.
             </p>
             <p>
              Once it hits this point, there is no reasoning with those emotionally involved. At least with this issue it doesn't look like a splinter group will form with the sole purpose of bitterly complaining about kos.
             </p>
             <p>
              Don't let it get you down. Sanity will prevail in about a week.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              Don't make me use my "special nerd powers" on you.

               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 The kind of people who would be driven off
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/364689/12784206#c1035?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1035">
                  0+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 by the likes of me probably aren't cut out for Daily Kos in the first place. It's a rough and tumble world around here and you need to be ready to defend whatever you say, and go to the mat for things you believe in.
                </p>
                <p>
                 One of the things I believe in is the quality of this community and the fact that it has been making quite a great deal of
                 <em>
                  progress
                 </em>
                 throughout its many long years of existence, and so I take it as an invitation to the mat when people make snotty comments, like you did today, about the quality of the community. Especially people who, like yourself, appear only to have bothered relatively recently to make a contribution themselves.
                </p>
                <p>
                 I'm only defending my Own, you see, from someone I see as an interloper impugning them. I see this as a noble quality, actually.
                </p>

        <li id="c847">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12782450">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Cowardice v. Courage
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12782450#c847?mode=alone;showrate=1#c847">
             9+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:4828">
              XOVER
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:5795">
              klugerEsel5
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:18605">
              opinionated
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:34222">
              aggressiveprogressive
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:63264">
              viscerality
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:90840">
              godislove
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:93618">
              mdgarcia
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:93802">
              0wn
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:112421">
              wyvern
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Mike's got the courage of his convictions. Mealy-mouthed, whiney "concern trolls" here who would criticize his tactics, even as they join in the strategy, certainly have not got any courage, much less convictions.
           </p>
           <p>
            If you want to fight, you've got to get in there and be willing to put yourself in the line of fire like Mike has done.
           </p>
           <p>
            If you want to grouse here at DailyKos, that's fine. Everybody plays their part, no matter how small.
           </p>
           <p>
            But criticizing a comrade who has the guts to confront your joint enemy, is really just as bad as the College Republicans supporting a war they aren't willing to serve in.
           </p>
           <p>
            They're cowards for that. And, in my view, if you're criticizing Mike Stark for standing UP FOR YOU in the only way O'Reilly "gets," then you're just as much of a coward.
           </p>
           <p>
            And, shame on you for it.
           </p>
           <p>
            Recommended Mike, because YOU DESERVE IT. You earned it.
           </p>
          </div>

              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                I Was There In The 60s
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/364689/12783998#c1016?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1016">
                 4+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:63264">
                  viscerality
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:90840">
                  godislove
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:102176">
                  Oreo
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:104129">
                  rrheard
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                I was there and was a part of it, so your "screw you" is just laughable. I was there in DC when we threw horseshit on the Capitol Steps and were arrested and beaten about the head. I was there for Kent State students getting shot, the antiwar movement, the SDS and AIM. I was THERE when Berkeley was shut down by protesters. When Watts went up in flames, I remember it well. I was there when this country rose up and fought back against the War, when John F. Kerry spoke out to Sen. Fulbright publicly in the hearings against the war. I was there to see this entire country in social and political upheaval that puts Mike's actions in perspective.
               </p>
               <p>
                Get upset over a few paltry and TRUE signs about Bill O'Reilly and the distribution of a court transcript and confronting him on his driveway?
               </p>
               <p>
                <strong>
                 As I said, and I stand by it: Mike's got the courage of his convictions. The "concern trolls" have neither courage or conviction
                </strong>
                .
               </p>
              </div>

             <ul class="cm i1" id="k12784974">
              <li id="c1118">
               <div class="cx" id="cx12785392">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  You're Clearly Young Enough to Enlist
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/364689/12785392#c1118?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1118">
                   1+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="crs">
                 <dl>
                  <dt>
                   Recommended by:
                  </dt>
                  <dd>
                   <a href="/user/uid:104129">
                    rrheard
                   </a>
                  </dd>
                 </dl>
                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  Obviously, a coward who wasn't there in the 60s.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Your statement about it was the first hint, but your Beavis and Butthead level of intellect just proves it beyond a doubt.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Your words again:
                 </p>
                 <blockquote>
                  <p>
                   "hahahahaha"
                  </p>
                 </blockquote>
                 <p>
                  It sounds like "heh-heh-heh" when read by viewers. You're making a complete ass of yourself, but whatever. I'll defend your right to humiliate yourself.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Here are your own words, coward:
                 </p>
                 <blockquote>
                  <p>
                   <em>
                    what did we do in '06? we didn't lower ourselves (0 / 0)
                    <br/>
                    to tawdry stunts and moronic dialog.
                   </em>
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   we directly engaged the electorate and won.
                  </p>
                 </blockquote>
                 <p>
                  Those are
                  <strong>
                   your words comparing the 60s to what Mike Stark did.
                  </strong>
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  I responded by pointing out that you are lying about the 60s. It's clear that you are, since you don't have the first clue about them if you think the antiwar movement was nothing but engaging the electorate. I was there during the 60s, and in fact, your nice little description of what happened and what turned things around then is laughable.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  We didn't just
                  <em>
                   "directly engage the electorate",
                  </em>
                  we took over administration offices and shut down entire university's; we were arrested for throwing horse manure on the Capital steps; we were shot at, beaten, and thrown in jail. We were involved in social upheaval on a huge scale. There were riots, mass demonstrations, student shootings, and civil disobedience. Kent State? The '68 Democratic Convention? People were not afraid to engage in a million "accountability moments."
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  That was an entire movement of Mike Starks. My point was that Mike's action doesn't deserve your criticism or contempt--he deserves congratulations for having the courage of his convictions. You have neither courage or conviction if you think that the 60s is described by "we engaged the electorate."
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  We didn't consider ourselves the least bit "tawdry" your description of Mike Stark
                  <em>
                   --such a sanctimonious and pathetic troll word, after all--
                  </em>
                  and we certainly weren't "moronic."
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   The only thing moronic is your argument--for thinking Bill O'Reilly would respond to your "decency and class." You clearly don't have any.
                  </strong>
                 </p>
                </div>
                <div class="cf">
                 <p class="sig">
                 </p>
                 <p class="cb">
                  by
                  <a href="/user/uid:62144">
                   SignalSuzie
                  </a>
                  on
                  <a href="/comments/364689/12785392#c1118">

              <ul class="cm i1" id="k12785392">
               <li id="c1267">
                <div class="cx" id="cx12788655">
                 <h5>
                  <a class="de">
                  </a>
                  <span class="cu">
                   You might want to read it again
                  </span>
                  <span class="crd ntb">
                   (
                   <a href="/comments/364689/12788655#c1267?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1267">
                    4+ / 0-
                   </a>
                   )
                  </span>
                 </h5>
                 <div class="crs">
                  <dl>
                   <dt>
                    Recommended by:
                   </dt>
                   <dd>
                    <a href="/user/uid:5795">
                     klugerEsel5
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:6921">
                     musing85
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:24682">
                     lorri
                    </a>
                    ,
                    <a href="/user/uid:101614">
                     crose
                    </a>
                   </dd>
                  </dl>
                 </div>
                 <div class="ct">
                  <blockquote>
                   <p>
                    Those are your words comparing the 60s to what Mike Stark did
                   </p>
                  </blockquote>
                  <p>
                   Actually, he/she said "in '06" -- unless dyslexia is a factor, I'm pretty sure that was last year.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   If you're going to ride in on a wave of indignation, I just think you might want to be responding to what someone actually says.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   Frankly, I'm not too concerned about being labeled a "coward" for disliking Mike's tactics. You want to follow the whole war metaphor with "battles" and "comrades", that's fine. But in war, it is rarely a good idea to sacrifice long term strategy for a quick, feel-good tactical victory.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   There were better ways to go about this that would have the same spirit.
                  </p>
                 </div>

                  <p class="sig">

         <li id="c1272">
          <div class="cx" id="cx12788703">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             I find it interesting
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/364689/12788703#c1272?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1272">
              1+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:101614">
               crose
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             that someone who's been here far less time than I have is presuming to lecture me on how things are done at dKos. The problem is not with Mr. Stark's courage or his convictions. No one is saying he had no right to confront O'Lielly. But what we have problems with is with him thinking that he had the right to drag this site into his personal fight with someone else, and make it appear as if he did so with official backing. As a quick glance at the FAQ will demonstrate, Mike Stark has no authority to speak for this site--a point that I guarantee you Falafel-Boy will ignore when he fumes about this on the air.
            </p>
            <p>
             We're not "concern trolls." We're just concerned for the reputation of this site and the community that we've helped to build here. Unlike Mr. Stark and some of his more vociferous supporters, including you.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             Michael
             <br/>
             <a href="http://musing85.typepad.com" rel="nofollow">
              Musing's musings
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:6921">
              musing85
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/364689/12788703#c1272">

        <li id="c852">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12782478">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Unfortunately
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12782478#c852?mode=alone;showrate=1#c852">
             6+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:15714">
              delver rootnose
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:34471">
              astronautagogo
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:65678">
              pico
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:103503">
              bethyb
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:112640">
              Unbill
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:128110">
              BlueGenes
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <br/>
           Now BillO has grounds to obtain a restraining order against you, Mike. dammit. (You don't want one of those on your record, it also gets into your credit file.) I'm sure any judge will agree with BillO that your coming so close to his home and posting those defaming signs constitutes a reasonable "threat" to his "person". dammit.
           <p>
            Mike, I've always been a fan of all the political-stunt activism that you do. Courageous and justified, every time.
           </p>
           <p>
            But this seems much more like what the wing nuts would do, not a Kossack (much as we may want to!).
           </p>
           <p>
            (Chillingly brings to mind, for me, the harassing, threatening actions of the Scienotologists (deliberately misspelled) in the early to mid '90's. This is exactly what they did to all their detractors and to Scienos who tried to leave the [cult] hive, (especially) even down to distributing the "pervert" accusations to all the neighbors and picketing the house with signs.  I deplored the actions then and I have to object to it now. The difference is, though, that the Scienos would "manufacture" the "pervert" allegations. I can't say that you have slandered BillO.)
           </p>
           <p>
            I recommend that you delete this diary here, Mike, and maybe keep it posted on your own site.
           </p>
           <p>
            That said, I still thank you for your activist chutzpah!
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:31022">
             sockpuppet
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/364689/12782478#c852">
             Tue Jul 31, 2007 at 09:00:31 AM PDT

           </p>
           <p class="cl">

          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <li id="c855">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12782493">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            I am conflicted about this as well
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12782493#c855?mode=alone;showrate=1#c855">
             2+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:1620">
              DavidW in SF
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:90318">
              blue vertigo
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            This certainly appears to be "payback time".
           </p>
           <p>
            What should have been emphasized in the diary from the very first is that O'Reilly had started the fight by issuing threats to Stark. But in fairness, Stark presumably was harassing O'Reilly as the first dance step in this situation.
           </p>
           <p>
            I found the Jet Blue ambush interview really creepy and I do not like it when Michael Moore does that either. It is manipulative and bullying. We can stipulate that O'Reilly is a toad and a thug. No arguments there. We can also stipulate that Fox News is a nasty and dishonest piece of work. But where do we go from there? I am not thrilled with what Stark did, particularly since putting up signage seems to stray over into the wierdness of anti-abortion cults.
           </p>
           <p>
            The question really is, how does one respond to Rupert Murdock and Roger Ailes? Those are the grinning theoreticians behind O'Reilly. BillO is just the trigger man, the street muscle, for the two older ideologues who are pulling his strings. Are they above reproach because they are so powerful? There may be good and sufficient grounds for yanking Murdock's citizenship. Without US citizenship Murdock would need to sell off a chunk of his media holdings. Mistakes can often be corrected. How Murdock runs his "news channels" appears to me to show contempt for our system of government. Must we tolerate that, just because he has allied himself with a corrupted political party, that he is helping to further corrupt? Think about it. When do we stand up and say "Enough".
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">

          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Before you condemn Mike
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">

            <a href="/comments/364689/12782680#c884?mode=alone;showrate=1#c884">

            ...Need to come all the way off in the way we deal with these loathsome, unamerican traitors, like bill-O.            <div class="ct">
            <p>
             I cringe whenever I read things like this.
            </p>
            <p>
             What is the difference between someone here calling Billo a traitor and him calling liberals (or anyone who doesn't think the same way he does) traitors?
            </p>
            <p>
             Does our "correct" way of thinking justify our acting like the opposition?
            </p>
            <p>
             Don't you think that maybe, just maybe, we should think, act, behave, at least a couple of notches above someone like Billo?
            </p>
            <p>
             I would love to see those of us with opinions that differ from the Republicans act (and write) with some principles that are not like the very people we are criticizing...]
            </p>
            <p>
             Just my opinion.
            </p>

          <li id="c1487">
           <div class="cx" id="cx12796690">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              You sound like my mom and not in a good way.
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/364689/12796690#c1487?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1487">
               0+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              <em>
               Don't you think that maybe, just maybe, we should think, act, behave, at least a couple of notches above someone like Billo?
              </em>
             </p>
             <p>
              No. The only way to deal with a bully is to bloody his nose.
             </p>
             <p>
              <em>
               I would love to see those of us with opinions that differ from the Republicans act (and write) with some principles that are not like the very people we are criticizing...]
              </em>
             </p>
             <p>
              Then you would love to see the right wing continue to hold power.
             </p>
             <p>
              After almost 30 years of abuse, dating back to when Ronald Reagan brought the so-called Moral Majority into the mainstream of the Rethuglican Party, we can see where the values of civility and taking the high road have gotten us.
             </p>
             <p>
              Among other things, these values have gotten us the worst president in U.S. history and a quagmire in Iraq. These values have also gotten liberals the reputation of being wimps -- not an image you want to have when national security is a top election issue.
             </p>
             <p>
              What goody two-shoes like you forget is that all of this is taking place not in a high school civics class or at the dinner table but in a political environment that rewards aggressive attacks and penalizes civility.
             </p>
             <p>
              The day when American voters pull the lever for the soft-spoken candidate is the day to change back to a more civil tone of voice.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              The truth doesn't need a noise machine. It just needs people who will stand up for it.

          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Mike, I have always been one of your biggest fans
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12782771#c898?mode=alone;showrate=1#c898">
             11+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:1620">
              DavidW in SF
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:13651">
              bsmcneil
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:24682">
              lorri
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:28222">
              sele
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:35947">
              Catte Nappe
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:65678">
              pico
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:65877">
              evanaj
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:69254">
              Absit invidia
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:81841">
              pkbarbiedoll
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:103503">
              bethyb
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:128110">
              BlueGenes
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            and supporters, but I gotta join the naysayers in this one - I think it's way, WAY too much to go to a person's house.
           </p>
           <p>
            I think it borders on harrassment.
           </p>
           <p>
            I get outraged when people go to abortion docs houses. I feel outraged when people like Michael Shiavo were accosted at their houses. If anyone showed up at my house, I'd be over the moon livid.
           </p>
           <p>
            I don't agree when the paparrazi accost bad-behaving celebs at their homes. I work in entertainment with celebs of various levels and I see a lot of it. Some of my professional colleagues (actors/on-air personalities and not always big ones at that) have to travel with body guards because of various threats that might or might not be real.
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             These people tell me how it feels to not know who could be waiting outside the door of your home. To not be able to even walk your dog in peace. One of these people is a star who is a very young, sweet, innocent woman. Because of just one stalker threat - just one! - she can't even go to a restaurant or movie or shopping alone.
            </strong>
           </p>
           <p>
            And as much as I admire Michael Moore as a filmmaker (and I'm a filmmaker, and he is one hell of an amazing one!), it bothered me when he went to Charlton Heston's home - I worked with Heston way back at the beginning of my career, I was over my head (directing a PSA at age 20 w/no experience) and he was a total gentleman and pro. He's not a bad guy - just has done a lot of things I vehemently disagree with.
           </p>
           <p>
            Even the mafia don't harass each other's families.
           </p>
           <p>
            O'Reilly is an asshole and a fool - and as cagey-smart as he is, I don't think he and I would have much competition in the IQ department. But I think even he deserves to have some peace when he comes home from a long day of lying on the air, spreading hate and spitting on the Constitution.
           </p>
           <p>
            I totally get the point you were trying to make, MIke.
           </p>
           <p>
            But I strongly disagree with the way you made it.
           </p>
          </div>

           </span>

            <a href="/comments/364689/12782819#c902?mode=alone;showrate=1#c902">

          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Now that I have your attention:
           </p>
           <p>
            I think this is great! I am not an activist progressive. I would never think to pull a stunt like this. But I've got to say, O'Reilly deserved it.
           </p>
           <p>
            He has declared WAR on the netroots, probably at the behest of higher ups, since it now appears to be a multipronged Fox Opinion assault on factual websites.
           </p>
           <p>
            We can't let O'Reilly sit too comfortably in his ivory tower studio, firing his missives without knowing we will fight back. He is now on notice.
           </p>
           <p>
            Bravo for Mike and friends. Now, let's see Falafel Bill's response, as well as how the news media reports this, if they do.
           </p>
           <p>
            As for those concerned that this stunt has lowered us to O'Reillian tactics. Hardly. No one threatened O'Reilly, They just presented him with the truth he's so busy bullying people to keep concealed. Welcome to the bright lights of the progressive internets, BillO!

            Funny, I was just discussing you this morning with my teenage son. He was praising prank callers getting through to C-SPAN and other media outlets, and I mentioned how you would regularly get through O'Reilly's radio show and if you ever mentioned Keith Olbermann's name, he'd threaten to send Fox security over to your house. I told him you'd received a threatening phone call from Fox Security. He thought that was hilarious. Oh, and he knew who you were because of the scuffle with the Allen guys last fall.
            <br/>
            I'll have to tell him about this, but I can't tell him I think it's a good idea. I mean, I think it's fine for you to let O'Reilly know you're not afraid of his thugs, and to visit his house to let him know what it's like to be on the receiving end of this type of behavior. I've gotta hand it to you, you've got guts.
            <br/>
            Not sure about the posters and flyers, though. Seems to me like doing one or the other (either confronting him at his home OR posting signs/distributing flyers) would be easier to condone, but having done all of the above at the same time is a bit too much for people to take. I personally would not want anyone to visit me at my home, but then again I'm not a celebrity who constantly threatens to do the same to anyone who disagrees with him.
            <br/>
            So I have to give you kudos, Mike, but then I also feel the need to wag my finger and tell you to behave!

              See I just don't agree with that. My hero was
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/364689/12783834#c996?mode=alone;showrate=1#c996">
               0+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>

            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              Albert Ellis who just died at 93. His book Rational Emotive Therapy convinced me it's wonderful to be able to have some control over your emotions by thinking about them rationally. To me that increases my happiness and my ability to attempt in some teensy weensy way to make this a better world.
              <br/>
              I'm pretty sure you and I would have lots of good conversations if we ran across each other in most diaries here. This diary has pitted us against each other. How is that good?
              <br/>
              There's another good book called Parent Effectiveness Training. I think the author makes a brilliant case that it's not good to be either passive or aggressive but rather to be assertive. I have to look up the author. I will add it as a reply to this comment.

              ps I'm not in favor of being an emotionless dullard. I laughed hysterically at Condoleaser's diary right before I read this one.

           <li id="c1566">
            <div class="cx" id="cx12815807">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               Think about it
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/364689/12815807#c1566?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1566">
                0+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               This site is effective because it's credible. Pulling crap like this takes away from that credibility. It will make it harder to attract support, and also to build or to keep the kind of relationships with the movers and shakers that we have enjoyed thus far.
              </p>
              <p>
               I don't know that nothing can ever destroy this site. I've seen a fair amount of attempts to do just that in the nearly four years I've been a member--and I see more and more of those with every day that passes. Some are intentional, others not.
              </p>
              <blockquote>
               <p>
                This is how the rightwing has been playing it all along. This is how they have maintained power.
               </p>
              </blockquote>
              <p>
               And that ought to be all the reason we need not to emulate them. When they pull stunts like this, we scream bloody murder. We should scream no less loudly when it's one of our own doing the stunting.
              </p>

           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Fight Fire With
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12783066#c931?mode=alone;showrate=1#c931">
             1+ / 0-
            </a>

            <dt>

             <a href="/user/uid:69938">

             </a>
            </dd>

          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Conflagration. Some may call it a stunt. Tactics
            <br/>
            aside, it had the desired effect, now did it not?
            <br/>
            The more attention lavished on the big bad Left, so much the better.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:61866">
             cschabes
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/364689/12783066#c931">
             Tue Jul 31, 2007 at 09:24:49 AM PDT
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <li id="c937">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12783127">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Mike, don't listen to these people
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12783127#c937?mode=alone;showrate=1#c937">
             6+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:4828">
              XOVER
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:15060">
              rlamoureux
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:18605">
              opinionated
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:34222">
              aggressiveprogressive
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:85179">
              AmericanRiverCanyon
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:104129">
              rrheard
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            What you are doing is good-old-fashioned muck-raking. There is along tradition of advocacy journalism in this country. It's too bad that this has atrophied of the years. Newspapers used to have names like "Democrat" and "Republican" and "Union" on the mast-head. In fact, some still do. Why? Because such newspapers were owned and operated by those very groups. You knew who was spinning the story, and because of this, you could
            <em>
             figure out why
            </em>
            they were spinning the story. Nowadays, the lies come in a nice non-partisan package, more easily digested by the unwashed masses.
           </p>
           <p>
            I say bring back the days of partisan, bare-knuckled, advocacy journalism. Mike Stark should be commended for being one of the few who is willing to lead this vanguard.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            "I must create a system or be enslaved by another man's."
                                    -  William Blake
           </p>

            <li id="c1132">
             <div class="cx" id="cx12785585">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                What about Ken Starr?
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/364689/12785585#c1132?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1132">
                 2+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:18605">
                  opinionated
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:90840">
                  godislove
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                There were protesters in front of his home for months, if I remember correctly. I didn't have a problem with that, either.
               </p>
               <p>
                The reason I feel this way, is that people who seek positions of power -- in which they will have authority over the lives of many individuals -- have, by virtue of such, abdicated a certain amount of privacy. It simple comes with the territory.
               </p>
               <p>
                This being said, would I prefer a world in which such types of direct actions would be unnecessary? Sure. But we cannot restore the water in which we all swim while the arbitors of acceptable political discourse in this country -- Fox News, Savage, Lou Dobbs, et al -- are still dumping their noxious effluent upstream. No, we have to go to the source and shut the pollution down.
               </p>
               <p>
                We need to tell the truth about O'Reilly, bully, creep, would-be rapist, and all-around stain on humanity that he is. I applaud Mike for his guts and for getting this stuff into the public mind.
               </p>
               <p>
                And it's nice to have a civil disagreement about something, no? Kind of what democracy is all about.
               </p>
              </div>

        <li id="c960">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12783394">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            To those who call this a smear...
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12783394#c960?mode=alone;showrate=1#c960">
             13+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:2029">
              Oregon guy
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:2312">
              jps
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:18605">
              opinionated
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:25761">
              Boston to Salem
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:75436">
              gotalife
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:85179">
              AmericanRiverCanyon
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:88630">
              sccs
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:90840">
              godislove
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:93802">
              0wn
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:94009">
              Unionman
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:101902">
              davefromqueens
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:102952">
              thursdays child
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:107627">
              posse comitatus
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Are you the same ones who believe in "fair and balanced"? Are you the type who tells people, "well, I like to hear both sides."
            <br/>
            All that tells me is that you don't know right from wrong, can't tell the difference between truth and lies.
            <br/>
            You see, there are no two sides to TRUTH. Truth
            <em>
             is
            </em>
            , it cannot be altered by opinion. Confronting Billo is holding a mirror up in his face.
            <br/>
            WE THE PEOPLE have little recourse for confronting people like O'Reilly. We're frustrated and angry that the MSM treats Fox as though they are just another media news outlet, when they themselves (Fox) have admitted that they have the right to lie in telling the news (notice I don't say reporting the news. You can't report if you're just pulling it out of your ass). Their intent is propaganda. And I am sick and tired of having people say that we cannot confront them for those lies. We have to be nice. Bull. Would you have wanted to be nice to Goebbels? Not much difference.
            <br/>
            WE THE PEOPLE are once again moving forward to take this country back from the fascists (i.e. corporations, look it up) that have taken it over.
            <br/>
            As with any revolution, there will always be appeasers. They were there before the Revolutionary War, as with every war since.
            <br/>
            But difficult times call for difficult decisions. Giving Billo a taste of his own medicine, while it won't accomplish anything, since he's such a psychopath himself, gives me cause to think that confronting that blowhard is a good thing, that people are finally beginning to realize that we don't have to take it anymore.
            <br/>
            The more we allow Billo, Rush, Bush, Cheney, the Christian Right, and others to knock us down, to force US to apologize to them for, essentially screwing the American public day after day, the longer they will be around.
            <br/>
            Sorry, but this is war. It is a war for the truth. It is a war for justice. It is a war for the very heart and soul (not to mention Constitution and Bill of Rights) of this country.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            "Keep raisin' hell!" - Molly Ivins

        <li id="c973">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12783602">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            I Trust You Have A Good Lawyer...
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12783602#c973?mode=alone;showrate=1#c973">
             2+ / 0-
            </a>
            )

          </h5>

             </a>

             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            my friend.
           </p>
           <p>
            Mr. O'Reilly may or may not have a winning case against you, but I will be surprised if he does not sue you for harrassment and defamation, regardless of whether you are legally OK, within your rights.
           </p>
           <p>
            Good luck!
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            Steve Wild
            <br/>
            <a href="http://www.dailyspeech.net" rel="nofollow">
             Daily Speech
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:48351">
             slw0606
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/364689/12783602#c973">
             Tue Jul 31, 2007 at 09:44:25 AM PDT
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <ul class="cm i1" id="k12783602">
         <li id="c1033">
          <div class="cx" id="cx12784189">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             O'Liely defames himself publicly on a daily basis
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/364689/12784189#c1033?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1033">
              0+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             so defamation may not be an issue. Also, harrassment can be charged, I believe, IF once you're told to stop, you continue your harrassing activities. Harrassment is an action toward someone, phone, at home, work, mail, etc., that continues to occur over and over. The person feeling harrassed, I believe, has to make a clear statement of stopping toward the harrasser. Been there..."did you tell them to stop it? That the [action] is not welcome and make the statement clear?" It comes down to that in most instances. If Bill told him to go away and not come back, or to stay off his property, then Bill would have some leverage if he chose to press charges and Mike still returned anyway. Anybody agree/disagree with the basics here?
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             Never grow a wishbone, daughter, where your backbone ought to be.  Clementine Paddeford
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:95453">
              blubryeyes
             </a>

         <li id="c1038">
          <div class="cx" id="cx12784241">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Moral cowardice?
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/364689/12784241#c1038?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1038">
              2+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:18605">
               opinionated
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:94009">
               Unionman
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             This is still a free country, isn't it? Although I blog here, I'm confident that my words and actions are my own. Do you really think every comment illustrates the character or goals of the entire community? Get real, if that's the way you think, you should join the Republicans. They're very into censorship and cowardice. I can't see a position like this as anything else. We're in a fight. If you think you're ever going to get anywhere with this group fighting with charm school etiquette, you might as well give up now and enjoy the last few years we have as the planet warms and is eventually, destroyed. If that's not worth active confrontation and as you call them, "bullshit stunts," than why are we even bothering in the first place?
             <br/>
             Moral cowardice blows back ten-fold and we're in this position now because we have let the liars define the whole game. Wake up and get on board instead of going after someone you probably ultimately agree with. It truly is, us against them.
            </p>
           </div>

          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Life Imitates Art for Novelist Bill O'Reilly
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12783883#c1003?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1003">
             1+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:119218">
              North Country Dem
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Overlooked in the salacious details of O'Reilly's tawdry talk to his subordinate is the years of practice he got earlier - as a novelist. In his 1998 novel,
            <em>
             Those Who Trespass
            </em>
            , Bill O'Reilly showed he could write - as well as talk - trash.
           </p>
           <p>
            For the details, see:
            <br/>
            <strong>
             <a href="http://www.perrspectives.com/blog/archives/000699.htm">
              "Life Imitates Art for Novelist Bill O'Reilly."
             </a>
            </strong>

            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/364689/12784569#c1064?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1064">
              6+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>

           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             You think his neighbors will be happy about this?
            </p>
            <p>
             And you think they will blame O'Reilly for it?
            </p>
            <p>
             You think they don't already know Bill O'Reilly lives there?
            </p>
            <p>
             You don't think they've been hoping this sort of nonsense wouldn't happen in their neighborhood, and you think that they'll be
             <em>
              happy
             </em>
             that it did?
            </p>

              </p>
              <p>
               As much as I hate Bill O, and I do, I find it strange that anyone would compare him to UBL and AQ and the leadership in Darfur and Sudan. I think you give him way too much credit. He isn't the anti-christ, he's just a big blowhard that most Americans do not take seriously.

            <li id="c1176">
             <div class="cx" id="cx12786580">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                I was not comparing BOR to UBL and AQ...
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/364689/12786580#c1176?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1176">
                 0+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                I just said that I feel contempt for them all, not to the same degree.
               </p>
               <p>
                Yes - he is not anti-Christ (that definition would fit Dick Cheney better), but if you do not realize how much damage this (by your definition)
                <strong>
                 big blowhard
                </strong>
                is doing, even if he has 29% deadenders taking him seriously, we will have to differ on our value judgements. He is poisoning the well of public discourse, and it does NOT need Valdemorts all to allow an atmosphere of this kind to slowly become the norm. The Republicans have shown that in spades - much less dangerous personalities have slowly added their voices to a bit of fascism in this country where it is OK to denigrate one group of citizens or other - immigrants, high schools that allow different viewpoints (including age appropriate sex education), university faculty. And BOR has been the loudest in adding to this swamp.
               </p>
               <p>
                One can say ignore blowhards like him and they will go away. In some cases it is true. But BOR still has a sizeable audience and is doing much more damage than normal blowhards.
               </p>
              </div>

           <div class="ct">

             When I first saw this early today, I kind of winced. Sure, the 9-year-old insinde me giggled. But I couldn't comment on it... didn't want to even give any other commentsd a rec.
            </p>
            <p>
             Now, in looking over the whole, thing, I'm telling my inner-9-year-old to zip it. This was a childish, boneheaded move.
            </p>
            <p>
             What really made me come down on the opposite side of Mike Start was this:
            </p>
            <blockquote>
             <p>
              Wanted to address the naysayers: please take your concern to your own diaries.
             </p>
            </blockquote>
            <p>
             That pretty much says Mike doesn't get the whole idea of this virtual community and how it works.

           <p>
            Is what you do any different than the fundamentalists targeting doctors and nurses at their homes?
           </p>
           <p>
            That is pretty nasty business, so is yours.
           </p>
           <p>
            You might want to go home and rethink your life.
           </p>

             <p>

             </p>
             <blockquote>
              <p>
               But associating his prank with this site was way not cool.
              </p>
             </blockquote>
             <p>
              You don't speak for this site. And neither does Mike Stark. Here is a convenient list for you to see who
              <em>
               <a href="http://www.dkosopedia.com/wiki/DailyKos_FAQ#Who_speaks_for_this_site.3F">
                does
               </a>
              </em>
              speak for this site:
             </p>
             <blockquote>
              <p>
               Who speaks for this site?
               <br/>
               (from Who "represents" Daily Kos? by kos, Tue Dec 12, 2006 at 09:35:47 AM PST)
              </p>
              <p>
               ... here's a quick rundown on who can "represent" Daily Kos.
              </p>
              <p>
               First of all, no one speaks for Daily Kos other than me. Period.
              </p>
              <p>
               Those who could be said to "represent" the site are the following Contributing Editors:
              </p>
              <p>
               BarbinMD
               <br/>
               Darksyde
               <br/>
               DavidNYC
               <br/>
               DeminCT
               <br/>
               Devilstower
               <br/>
               DHinMI
               <br/>
               Hunter (fellow)
               <br/>
               Georgia10
               <br/>
               KagroX
               <br/>
               Mcjoan (fellow)
               <br/>
               Meteor Blades
               <br/>
               MissLaura
               <br/>
               Plutonium Page
               <br/>
               SusanG (fellow)
               <br/>
               Trapper John
              </p>
              <p>
               On tech matters, Jeremy also "represents" the site.
              </p>
              <p>
               That's it.
              </p>
              <p>
               Update: Actually, that's not it. One more:
              </p>
              <p>
               Adam B. represents the site in regulatory and legal matters, and is also an occasional contributor on such issues.
              </p>
             </blockquote>
             <p>
              I'm sure that if Kos and/or the administration of this site have a problem with Mr. Stark's actions or posting about same here,
              <strong>
               they
              </strong>
              will let him know. There's no reason for you to worry about it.
             </p>
