          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Fine if you thought it was a wonderful idea and wanted to post it on your own web site. That way you could own the outcome of your actions. I think the stunt exhibited incredibly poor judgment, and the timing as our Democratic leadership prepare to engage with us in Chicago was horrible. And I hope you have a good lawyer.
           </p>
           <p>
            It's creepy when O'Reilly has his minions ambush the CEO of JetBlue as he leaves his home, and it's just as creepy when you do it. Adopting O'Reilly's tactics does you no credit.
           </p>
           <p>
            I think the response to the original O'Reilly flap by our candidates in supporting what we do here was admirable, and we've been very effective in highlighting O'Reilly's tactics and shining a spotlight on his lies. What you've done undermines much of the progress we've made.
           </p>
           <p>
            For the record: Count me among those who do not approve of your actions.
           </p>
           <p>
            And about this statement of yours:
            <em>
             If BillO's your hero, fine, concern-troll away all morning.
            </em>
            That says a lot. Thanks, Mike.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            <a href="http://www.democrats.org/page/outreach/view/bonds/DailyKosFor50States" rel="nofollow">
             DailyKos for 50 States
            </a>
            --
            <b>
             Let's Build It!
            </b>
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:1620">
             DavidW in SF
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/364689/12785694#c1139">

            </a>
           </p>

            Hey Mike:
           </p>
           <p>
            Maybe you don't get this whole "Kos Diary" thing, but if you don't like the legitimately-written negative responses to what you put up here, why don't
            <strong>
             you
            </strong>
            take it somewhere else?
           </p>
           <p>
            I'm not sayin' I'm for or against your latest move, btw. I honestly haven't made up my mind.
           </p>
           <p>
            So if you want an uncritical forum for your actions, maybe you can moderate your own site (to which I've contributed multiple times). Don't tell other people who have as much right to be here as you do that they're somehow not welcome on a diary at Kos, please.
           </p>
           <p>
            Thanks in advance for taking this constructively.

        <li id="c1190">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12786884">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            liberal circular firing squad, assemble!
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12786884#c1190?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1190">
             11+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:630">
              claude
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:3051">
              Inky
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:3930">
              vivacia
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:16522">
              madwayne
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:18262">
              checkmate
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:30304">
              chinkoPelinke
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:55142">
              IL dac
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:101902">
              davefromqueens
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:102952">
              thursdays child
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:103290">
              sabershadow
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:116091">
              Break On Through
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            I'm not writing this to be confrontational with the other posters in this thread who think that what Mike did was wrong, but this seems to illustrate a key point about Politics 2007--liberals, as a rule, do not like to bring knives to knife fights. I mean, maybe I've got it wrong, but it was O'Reilly who started this particular salvo by attacking DKos, right? and O'Reilly's reporters who went to the home of the guy from JetBlue, yah?
           </p>
           <p>
            in better times, I'm in complete agreement that guerrilla tactics like this are distasteful. THESE ARE NOT BETTER TIMES. one of the primary reasons that these times are so awful is the ascension of our lying Corporate Media, and Bill O'Reilly is one of that Corporate Media's most heinous, and eager, faces. if there is any chance at all that a widening of the awareness that O'Reilly is among the basest, most self-serving, of hypocrites (not to mention freaks) could come of this, it's got my blessings, not that it needs it.
           </p>
           <p>
            taking the country back by dint of pure reason isn't possible, I don't think. I think we've all hoped that somebody on some blog somewhere would write the key thing that would start a groundswell among the mass populace, and there've been many worthy attempts along those lines. but nothing's gained the necessary traction. I think the exploration of any and all non-violent alternatives is amply justified.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:70208">
             annagranfors
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/364689/12786884#c1190">
             Tue Jul 31, 2007 at 12:10:58 PM PDT
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <ul class="cm i1" id="k12786884">
         <li id="c1217">
          <div class="cx" id="cx12787464">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             I disagree
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/364689/12787464#c1217?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1217">
              2+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:24682">
               lorri
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:64746">
               Nowhere Man
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             "taking the country back by dint of pure reason isn't possible, I don't think." I think that's a grossly unfair assessment of the public's intelligence. From everything I've read, a majority of the country favors the progressive agenda. So if they're already leaning towards our side, it seems like reason is about all they'd need to be won over. Stunts like this only fuel the perception that we're nutbags with little else to do but show up at people's houses and hurl insults and turn people off.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:128477">
              PLCOT
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/364689/12787464#c1217">
              Tue Jul 31, 2007 at 12:45:52 PM PDT
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cl">
             [
             <a href="#c1190">
              Parent
             </a>
             ]
            </p>
           </div>
          </div>
         </li>
         <li id="c1244">
          <div class="cx" id="cx12788149">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             This isn't bringing a knife to a knife fight
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/364689/12788149#c1244?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1244">
              0+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             Consider: If dKos is as powerful a medium as Faux is, then we do best by fighting back right here with our keyboards.
            </p>
            <p>
             And if dKos still does not have as much reach as Faux does (which I'd guess is still the case), then Mike has handed O'Reilly a ton of raw stock for his propaganda machine. And as with all of his ravings, we'll be unable to clean up the pollution as fast as he can spew it out.
            </p>
            <p>
             A stunt like this may make you feel good for a while, but that's all it does: make you feel good. Feeling good doesn't win the battle for you.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             <b>

        <li id="c1197">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12787036">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            "Pervert"? Ever heard of slander 'per se'?
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12787036#c1197?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1197">
             1+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:104398">
              ShaunMcDonnell
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            <a href="http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&amp;q=%22pervert%22+slander+per+se&amp;btnG=Search">
             http://www.google.com/...
            </a>
           </p>
           <blockquote>
            <p>
             The only exception to the rule that the plaintiff must prove special, or actual damages caused by a slander, is where the slander is deemed by the law to be so egregious as to amount to a presumption that the plaintiff has been injured by it. This is known as "slander per se," and is limited to the following types of utterances: (1) where the defendant has charged that the plaintiff has committed a serious, morally reprehensible crime, or that he has been incarcerated in a prison for such a crime; (2) where the defendant imputes a presently existing loathsome, communicable disease to the plaintiff (historically limited to venereal disease and leprosy, although it would clearly include AIDS today); (3) where the defendant has attributed to the plaintiff conduct, characteristics or associations incompatible with the plaintiff's business, trade, office or profession such that the natural and expected consequence of anyone who hears it and believes it true, would refuse to do business, or cease doing business with, the plaintiff; (4) and (4) where the defendant imputes unchastity to a woman. (5)...
            </p>
           </blockquote>
           <blockquote>
            <p>
             ...However, if he were to be accused falsely of being a sex pervert, ... This is known as "slander per se,"
            </p>
           </blockquote>
           <p>
            Its quite possible that O'Reilly will file suit under the slander/defamation per se doctrine and force you to prove he is indeed a "pervert". Granted, you have a decent shot at proving the "truth" of your allegation against O'Reilly... but did you HAVE to use such a legally-weighted term to prove your point today?
           </p>
           <p>
            Just BTW, it will not be a detached judge who will determine the truth or falsity of the "pervert" charge. It will be a jury of O'Reilly's wealthy country-club neighbors out in Blueblood County, Yuppieville, NY.
           </p>
           <p>
            Who knows. Perhaps falafels are a routine part of their sexual culture out there.
           </p>
           <p>
            Good luck!
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:51155">
             farmbo
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/364689/12787036#c1197">
             Tue Jul 31, 2007 at 12:20:40 PM PDT
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>

             This is not slander Per Se
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/364689/12791208#c1404?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1404">
              1+ / 0-
             </a>

            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:16704">
               expatjourno
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             The burden is on Oreilly to prove the accusations are false, not the other way around. Even then he would have to know that Mr. Stark knew the accusations was false, or was reckless(what the courts mean by reckless is he could have easily found out, but did not). As long as Mr. Stark reasonably believed the accusations to be true when he made them he is free from being charged with slander. Slander Is an extremely high standard.
            </p>
           </div>

              I'm normally polite.
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (

               1+ / 0-
              </a>

             </span>

            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:119034">
                MyOwnClone
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              Democrats have won three of the last 8 Presidential elections.
             </p>
             <p>
              I'm going to the dark side that tells the truth but understands the reality of of modern politics.
             </p>
            </div>

             Wanted to address the naysayers: please take your concern to your own diaries.
            </em>

           <p>
            Dude, I have no particular beef with what you did to O'Reilly, but its pretty lame to tell your critics to stop criticizing you in the comments to your story. That's what the comments are for. What you did was controversial and aggressive. There are good reasons to support you, and good reasons to be weary of such tactics. Both deserve to be aired. If you can't handle criticism, especially well-intentioned criticism, go get a blog without comments or join a community that censors critics.

          <div class="ct">
           <blockquote>
            <p>
             If BillO's your hero, fine, concern-troll away all morning. Just please do me the favor of taking it to your own diaries.
            </p>
           </blockquote>
           <p>
            You do not get to label members of this community any kind of troll for the simple fact of disagreeing with your tactics.
           </p>
           <p>
            Nor are comments telling people to go to LGF or join the Republican party simply because they disagree with this action acceptable.
           </p>
           <p>
            Without commenting on Mike Stark's action itself, I will say that I find the bullying, abuse, "with us or against us" mentality, and macho/homophobic/misogynist posturing displayed in comments here shameful.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">

           <p class="cb">

         <li id="c1413">
          <div class="cx" id="cx12791331">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Why not?
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/364689/12791331#c1413?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1413">
              0+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             <em>
              You do not get to label members of this community any kind of troll for the simple fact of disagreeing with your tactics.
             </em>
            </p>
            <p>
             It's not merely that they are disagreeing with the tactics. It's based on the reasoning for the disagreement. Some of the reasoning is indistinguishable from reasoning that in other contexts has been labeled concern trolling.
            </p>
            <p>
             <em>
              Nor are comments telling people to go to LGF or join the Republican party simply because they disagree with this action acceptable.
             </em>
            </p>
            <p>
             Is that contrary to some written or unwritten site rule? I'm not aware of any such rule.
            </p>
           </div>

            I like Mike
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">

            <a href="/comments/364689/12787840#c1233?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1233">

          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Mike unquestioningly assisted with the non-re-election of George Allen to the Senate. One less racist asshole in Congress. He did that by dressing up as a gorilla and by pursuing other "non-traditional" (crazy? inspired? sometimes confrontational?) means of getting out the message to people that something is rotten in our media and our body politic. Often at personal risk to himself, I might add.
           </p>
           <p>
            I don't know if this latest attempt will backfire or not. It depends on what O'Reilly does with it and the counter-response. I get that it's difficult for lots of folks here to stomach his tactics. But as a I read through the comments there are many good reminders of so-called "outrageous" acts that have in fact advanced progressive causes throughout history. The difference between us and Bill O'Reilly is not tactical. The difference is that he is filled with hate and we are not. Which is not to say that anything goes, but that when dealing with unrelenting and unrepentent bullies, a taste of their own medicine can be quite appropriate.
           </p>
          </div>

             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:120053">
              war is peace
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            I will not take it to my own diary. Not until you say that you'll protest Bill O'Reilly at your home and not his.
           </p>
           <p>
            No, I don't expect you to say that. You think you have a right to protest Bill O'Reilly at his home. Maybe you do. But in either case, I have at least as much right to disagree with you here.
           </p>
           <p>
            Mike, perhaps in the end you'll be proven right. I dunno. But I think you're a little quick to justify yourself.
           </p>
           <p>
            You write:
           </p>
           <blockquote>
            <p>
             Some have suggested that I'm not a journalist or a reporter because I engaged in advocacy while pursuing my work.
            </p>
            <p>
             Wrong.
            </p>
            <p>
             Michael Moore makes documentaries. It's journalism. It's legitimate. My diary and my movie will serve to inform. The fact that it's done in a novel way takes nothing away from the fact that I'm telling a story based on objective facts.
            </p>
           </blockquote>
           <p>
            I've never watched Michael Moore when he's at work making a film. Tell me, does he turn the
            <strong>
             shooting
            </strong>
            into a protest
            <em>
             cum
            </em>
            publicity event, or does he allow his films to deliver his message?
           </p>
           <p>
            You write:
           </p>
           <blockquote>
            <p>
             It's wrong to confront good people at their homes. It's absolutely the right thing to do to confront liars, cheats and fools that are fucking this country wherever and whenever you can find them.
            </p>
           </blockquote>
           <p>
            How certain are you that you can know the difference between good people and bad people? Do you think every American should be equally judgmental? Why or why not?
           </p>
           <p>
            You write:
           </p>
           <blockquote>
            <p>
             If BillO's your hero, fine, concern-troll away all morning.
            </p>
           </blockquote>
           <p>
            Honestly, Mike, if you hadn't written this, then I might have kept my
            <del>
             mouth shut
            </del>
            fingers off the keyboard. But
            <strong>
             how dare you
            </strong>
            suggest that I'm a fan of BillO simply because I disagree with your tactics?
            <strong>
             How dare you
            </strong>
            suggest that I'm a concern troll?
           </p>
           <p>
            You know less than you seem to think you do, Mike. A whole lot less.
           </p>

           </p>

            "If BillO's your hero, fine, concern-troll away all morning. Just please do me the favor of taking it to your own diaries."
           </p>
           <p>
            What are you going to do, lie about people (Ie, BillO's your hero if you disagree with me) and then turn off their mikes?

           <p>
            Okay, I don't want to hear about being a better person or just ignoring that idiot OReilly. Mike didn't cross any lines. Newsflash - OReilly has dedicated himself to belittling you. He is using a classic GOP trick: find out what your weakness' are then accuse your enemy of those same weaknesses before he can accuse you. You can't ignore O'reilly into shutting up; you have to stand up to him like any other bully. Go to his house. If you see him in the streets call him names. Bring the pressure and bring it hard. This is my problem with the Democrats; they just roll over and take the abuse. There are probably many people like me, people who would consider joining the Dems but wont because the Dems lack spines.
           </p>
           <p>
            GROW A PAIR!!!!!!!
           </p>
           <p>
            That is not to say physically accost him, obviously. But the same freedom of speech that allows O'Reilly to call each and every one of you a Nazi allows you to call him a @!#$!

           <span class="crd ntb">

            <a href="/comments/364689/12789082#c1292?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1292">
             9+ / 0-

          <div class="crs">
           <dl>

            <dd>

             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:102952">
              thursdays child
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            O'Reilly paid Mackris off.
            <strong>
             He stands behind the "you don't negotiate with terrorists" mantra every moment he breathes, and yet unless he just felt compelled to give away somewhere in the neighborhood of 10 million dollars to a woman he knew was lying, he just betrayed one of his own core principles.
            </strong>
            He claims to stand the ground for truth - why would he, and how could he ever justify his insistance that you not bargain with people at the same time he gave away more money than my father made in his lifetime five times over to "put the matter to rest".
           </p>
           <p>
            <em>
             <strong>
              If there was NO "matter" then there was no need to put it to rest.
             </strong>
            </em>
           </p>
           <p>
            Having said that, if Billo had gone to trial, by his own acts that payoff reveals his own admission thathe would likely been found guilty and then guess what - -
           </p>
           <ul>
            <li>
             (wait for it)
            </li>
           </ul>
           <p>
            <em>
             <strong>
              Then what Mike Stark did today would have been done by law to warn his neighbors that there was a convicted sex offender in their neighborhood.
             </strong>
            </em>
           </p>
           <p>
            So is what Stark did out of bounds?
           </p>
           <p>
            I don't consider the truth to be out of bounds, and I certainly don't believe that Kos or anyone on this site has to apologize for having spread that truth around.
           </p>
           <p>
            O'Reilly is a liar and a creepy scumbag. If he wants to prove otherwise, then here is his stage. But I don't think we must apolgize that his viewers are to blind/dumb/gullible to see the truth.
           </p>
          </div>

         <ul class="cm i1" id="k12789391">
          <li id="c1324">
           <div class="cx" id="cx12789642">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              I'm not sure the high ground
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/364689/12789642#c1324?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1324">
               0+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              is letting a liar keep lying and pretend we're beyond calling him on it just because the subject matter is lurid and perverted.
             </p>
             <p>
              Bill O'Reilly has brainwashed several million people into thinking his voice is that of a man with integrity, honesty, and sincerity. Why it is beyond the pale to tell the truth about a subject that O'Reilly paid 10 to 20 million dollars to have supressed is beyond me.
             </p>
             <p>
              I guess Billo would have been just fine with the idea that Bill Clinton could have paid Paula Jones 10 million to keep her story to herself, and we'd all be better off. Right?
             </p>
             <p>
              See my other comments upthread; if he had gone to court he would likely have been convicted (O'Reilly must have feared that more than losing the money, so it's not out of bounds to assume that) and as such, those signs and the stories behind them would have been given to his neighbors to inform them of a convicted sex offender in their neighborhood.
             </p>
             <p>
              I bet you most sex offenders who have had to endure their outing after their release wish like hell they had 10 million dollars to pay off whoever it was that got them convicted.
             </p>
             <p>
              I call it fair ball.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              George Orwell is banging on his coffin lid and screaming, "1984 was a cautionary tale, you dolts, not a motivational speech!"
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:76169">

              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
                Libertarian with a Social Conscience.
               </p>
               <p class="cb">
                by
                <a href="/user/uid:80142">
                 hegemony57
                </a>
                on
                <a href="/comments/364689/12792778#c1446">
                 Tue Jul 31, 2007 at 06:25:08 PM PDT
                </a>
               </p>
               <p class="cl">
                [
                <a href="#c1435">
                 Parent
                </a>
                ]
               </p>
              </div>
             </div>
            </li>
            <ul class="cm i1" id="k12792778">
             <li id="c1556">
              <div class="cx" id="cx12805486">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 This event in no way compares to the
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/364689/12805486#c1556?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1556">
                  1+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="crs">
                <dl>
                 <dt>
                  Recommended by:
                 </dt>
                 <dd>
                  <a href="/user/uid:6921">
                   musing85
                  </a>
                 </dd>
                </dl>
               </div>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 courage it took for a woman of color in the deep south to defy the white establishment during the fifties. A mere domestic, one of the few jobs available to women of color during that era. A woman who risked her employment and her life for a cause that was so much greater than all of us.
                </p>
                <p>
                 While it may be fun to post signs about O'Reilly's phone sex accusations around his neighborhood and to yell and argue with him in front of his house may be a cool political gig, but let's not get carried away with trying to associate it with some of the most important events of the Civil Rights Movement. It just does not measure up.
                </p>
                <p>
                 My comments are not intended to criticize Mike in any way because I am not in a position to know what the impact was, but instead to suggest there is no parallel between this modern day tactic and Rosa Parks refusing to move the the rear of the bus.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Nor, does it compare to the other black folks who chose to walk miles to their jobs and refused to use public transportation to highlight the importants of Rosa's actions. These actions were undertaken at great risk by negroes in the South at that time in history. There were still lynchings and pressure was put on white employers to control their negro domestics.
                </p>
                <p>
                 The domestics were essential to the fainting couche class of Southern lady of the 50s. Who would do the cleaning, marketing, cooking, and laundry. My goodness.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Rosa Parks actions started a chain of events that effected a high percentage of the Southern population. To attempt to compare it to this modern day, netroots hijinks doesn't hunt.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Peace,
                 <br/>
                 PaintyKat
                </p>
               </div>
               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                 <a href="http://www.tinyurl.com/v37ey" rel="nofollow">
                  WWYTR?
                 </a>
                 Voting, contributing, supporting, and electing Democrats
                </p>
                <p class="cb">
                 by
                 <a href="/user/uid:19309">
                  PaintyKat
                 </a>
                 on
                 <a href="/comments/364689/12805486#c1556">
                  Wed Aug 01, 2007 at 12:35:35 PM PDT
                 </a>
                </p>
                <p class="cl">
                 [
                 <a href="#c1446">
                  Parent
                 </a>

                </p>

             </p>
             <blockquote>
              <p>
               Main Entry: 4pussy
               <br/>
               Pronunciation: 'pu-sE
               <br/>
               Function: noun
               <br/>
               Inflected Form(s): plural pussies
               <br/>
               Etymology: short for pussycat
               <br/>
               slang :
               <strong>
                a weak or cowardly man or boy : WIMP, SISSY
               </strong>
              </p>
             </blockquote>
             <p>
              Your troll rating is misplaced as the usage was not in terms of a female body part. Perhaps you should learn the vernacular of the land; there's a richness in common speech!

               Now, if the poster had written "pursies"
              </span>

               <a href="/comments/364689/12790987#c1393?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1393">

             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               then I might have gone with the older meaning of the word which you refer to. But, fact is, the complex nature of double entendres are so deeply ingrained into our concepts of gender that the word is most definitely misogynistic either way.
              </p>
              <p>
               Maybe you can look up the word in an online dictionary and split hairs here, but I cannot.
              </p>

            <li id="c1514">
             <div class="cx" id="cx12797832">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                Pussy can also be a loving term...
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/364689/12797832#c1514?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1514">
                 0+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                I do not see the misogyny here. You understand that misogyny is a hatred of women, right? That was not the intent here, and "pussy" on its own, even when referring to a female body part, is not misogynistic. It can be crude, but that would be the best you can get. The intent behind it usage within the struture of a sentence may be misogynistic, but bitch, C**t, etc. would be more in place for that usage. In essence, misogyny is not a particular word but more an intent and action.
               </p>
               <p>
                You may not like the usage of the term where wimps or sissies was implied, but your troll rating is a badly misplaced attempt at chilling speech on a real "D" democratic blog.
               </p>
              </div>

                   </span>

                     <a href="/user/uid:6921">

                     </a>

                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    to avoid those terms and trollrating is standard procedure. Looks like some folks want to take advantage of the reduced size of the population to enforce their own rules but they won't hunt.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Bitch, pussie, and cunt are unsuitable for usage at dkos because they are sexist and reflect badly on the female population here. We have had some rocky times in this particular area and don't wish to revisit those troubled times.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    It really isn't difficult to make some adjustments in language usage in a public forum out of respect for others. That is the price we pay for being members of any group or society.
                   </p>

                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    In any endevour, degradation to the base, the
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/364689/12808358#c1562?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1562">
                     0+ / 0-
                    </a>

                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    "lowest common denominator" is always a concern. I do not see that occurring here even if crude speech is employed.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    What I see is passion, concern, frustration, and simple, pure, human emotion to set aright that which has been felled; our country and its ideals! These emotions based on the issues before us is what will create the power to solve these problems. Erudite discourse alone is not enough,
                    <em>
                     it never will be
                    </em>
                    ; although it has its place (design vs build). The reason is realty is moved by the the masses, and not everyone is a long thinking college educated strategist immersed in the gerbil wheel of details!
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    So, emotional, simple, language is the language of people; people are what makes democracy; so... use what works to make democracy work! The right wing understands this very well, and that is a good reason why they have been able to advance their agenda even against the desires and best interests of the people involved! they appeals to the emotions even if falsely.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Hence, you may not like the poster's use of "pussies" to chastise the timid here and you may not employ it yourself. That is certainly fine; it is your
                    <em>
                     personal choice
                    </em>
                    . However, to take the
                    <em>
                     action
                    </em>
                    and troll rate the poster on this was simply wrong!
                    <strong>
                     Your reason, "TR for misogynistic term", is muddled at best.
                    </strong>
                   </p>

            <li id="c1504">
             <div class="cx" id="cx12797031">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                "comment fodder" for right wing? -- Stop quaking
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/364689/12797031#c1504?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1504">
                 0+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                Your concern is so outrageous I'm not sure whether to take this seriously.
               </p>
               <p>
                Assuming your misguided worrying is actually made in good faith, please try to understand something. BillO IS "comment fodder" for the left. He is THEIR damage control problem.
               </p>
               <p>
                BillO is "comment fodder."
               </p>
               <p>
                BillO is a carnival joker and bigot. He is an infotainment personality who makes his living degrading people and lying. He hosts a Republican variety show which he falsely passes off as news.
               </p>
               <p>
                <strong>
                 BillO is THEIR "comment fodder" and this is the price Republicans pay for using him as a spokesperson for their cause on a Republican infotainment media network fraudulently passing its content as news.
                </strong>
               </p>
               <p>
                To leverage the "comment fodder" BillO keeps serving us, -- like fat pitches over the middle of the plate -- Democrats need to step up and "comment" on his lying hypocrisy. We need to make him the fodder he is. We also need to do it in his and their language.
               </p>
               <p>
                Mike Stark hit the ball over the fence.
               </p>
               <p>
                Advice: free yourself (and the rest of us) from living your life through the prism of Roger Aile's Republican propaganda. Use the "comment fodder" the right wing throws our way - if we dont our silence is taken as acceptance or weakness which is a far more dangerous fodder.
               </p>
               <p>
                It takes a lot of fight on many levels to win elections. Sitting in the back seat screaming, "slow down" will not get us anywhere on the Republican controlled media highway.
               </p>
              </div>

        <li id="c1373">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12790737">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            FDL shows why Mike's tactics are spot on!!
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12790737#c1373?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1373">
             7+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:3930">
              vivacia
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:4828">
              XOVER
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:21526">
              whenwego
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:44984">
              tymxposure
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:60733">
              Dem Soldier
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:101902">
              davefromqueens
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:102952">
              thursdays child
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            An interesting post at
            <a href="http://www.firedoglake.com/2007/07/30/status-quo-no-thanks/">
             FDL
            </a>
            discussing emotional vs. reasoned responses. I'll post a few salient points (emphasis mine):
           </p>
           <blockquote>
            <p>
             ...
            </p>
            <blockquote>
             <p>
              The philosopher David Hume had it right:
              <strong>
               Reason is the slave to the passions, not the other way around.
              </strong>
              Recognizing the primacy of passion in everything we do has profound implications for politics. ...
             </p>
             <p>
              ...
             </p>
             <p>
              <strong>
               If the other side is trashing you and you say nothing or back down, you cede to your adversaries
              </strong>
              the neural networks that constitute public opinion. P
              <strong>
               eople vote largely with their passions,
              </strong>
              and if you jam their emotional radar, you prevent them from making emotionally informed decisions. C
              <strong>
               onsider the case of George W. Bush, whose life story telegraphed everything voters needed to know to make an informed decision about him:
              </strong>
              He had dodged the Vietnam-era draft while avidly supporting the war; he had drunk his way through much of his adulthood, even while he had young children at home; he had shown extraordinary incompetence in the business world; his campaign had smeared Sen. John McCain with stories about mental instability and an allegedly illegitimate baby to get Bush through the South Carolina primary in 2000; and he had mocked a fellow born-again Christian whom he put to death as governor of Texas.
              <strong>
               It was quite a story. The problem was that the Democrats wouldnt tell it.
              </strong>
             </p>
            </blockquote>
            <p>
             Think about this for a moment: most people are too busy with the details of their everyday lives to pay attention to the minutiae. If the Democrats are the masters of the nitpicky details...where exactly does that leave them except in the dust? ...
            </p>
            <p>
             <strong>
              Go for the gut and the heart first.
             </strong>
            </p>
           </blockquote>
           <p>
            Check out the rest. It goes to the heart of why what Mike did is so spot on, so effective, and needs to be done more by all of us--
            <strong>
             call these criminals and bullies out already.
            </strong>
            <strong>
             Steel yourselves and stop whining because all the wingnuts will do is bury you,
             <em>
              dead
             </em>
             !
            </strong>
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            <em>
             The meek shall inherit the earth.... six feet under!!  Liberals and progressives, stop being meek!
            </em>
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:60373">
             FightTheFuture

           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Spot ON this ...
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/364689/12790849#c1379?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1379">
              4+ / 0-
             </a>

           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:4828">

              </a>

              <a href="/user/uid:44984">

              </a>

              <a href="/user/uid:101902">
               davefromqueens
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             ... there is no other way to fight bullies.
            </p>
            <p>
             If they use stong words you use strong words back.
            </p>
            <p>
             If they use fists you use fists back.
            </p>
            <p>
             If they pull out a knife you grab your blade.
            </p>
            <p>
             If they unholster a pistol you quick draw yours.
            </p>
            <p>
             If they flip the safety off of their assault rifle you pop a clip into your AK.
            </p>
            <p>
             We do not wish to start fights, we wish to end them.
            </p>
            <p>
             We do not pick on the weak, we defend them.
            </p>
            <p>
             We do not love war, we seek to avoid it if we can.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             Libertarian with a Social Conscience.
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:80142">
              hegemony57
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/364689/12790849#c1379">

         <ul class="cm i1" id="k12790849">
          <li id="c1389">
           <div class="cx" id="cx12790936">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              amen, Both hegemony and fight the future
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/364689/12790936#c1389?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1389">
               2+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:44984">
                tymxposure
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:60373">
                FightTheFuture
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              What many people in this thread do not understand (They're good people but are naive in this sense) is that the only way to fight back against evil is to stand your ground and push back just as hard.
             </p>
             <p>
              Do we desire this approach? No. But when O'Reilly threatens to go to people's homes, then Mike and all of us have every right to stand outside his with cameras.
             </p>
             <p>
              As for larger arguments, what these naysayers also don't understand is that if somebody is picking on you and you don't fight back, you lose that person's respect and thus their vote even if they agree with you on most issues.
             </p>
             <p>
              They also don't understand that although reason and logic are vital parts of a human being, emotional appeals also play a role in who someone votes for. If we don't appeal to people's emotions and feelings, we lose them even if our positions are completely logical and reasoned.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:101902">
               davefromqueens
              </a>

           <li id="c1451">

             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               Nah ...
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/364689/12792954#c1451?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1451">
                1+ / 0-
               </a>
               )

              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:44984">
                 tymxposure
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               ... we don't want to be the bully but we do want to stand up to bullies.
              </p>
              <p>
               I hate to bring this back to Jr. High School but that's the way it worked in my schoolyard and the way it worked for my 2 sons.
              </p>
              <p>
               BULLIES DO NOT STOP BULLYING UNTIL SOMEONE STANDS UP TO THEM AND GIVES THEM A BLOODY NOSE.
              </p>
              <p>
               So long as we are ready to fight when they start the bullying then we'll be fine.
              </p>
              <p>
               When we unilaterally disarm and think that words and reason can win the day every time we set ourselves up for being on the defensive and backpedaling.
              </p>
              <p>
               Why is it that so many of us LOVED Howard Dean?
              </p>
              <p>
               Is is because he had better arguments?
              </p>
              <p>
               No me.
              </p>
              <p>
               I loved him because he was willing to stand up to the chickenhawk motherfuckers and say "we're mad as hell and we're not gonna take it anymore".
              </p>
              <p>
               Amen.
              </p>
             </div>

Olbermann speaks for his cause and that's it. That is more honorable than nickel and diming certain situations for ratings. Yet, BillO, too, is a person.
           </p>
           <p>
            All of that said, damned be the person who ever goes to Keith Olbermann's house and takes the battle outside political boundaries.
           </p>
           <p>
            What Mr. Stark has done here is shameful and does nothing for the democratic cause and/or party. It elminates discourse and further pushes people apart.
           </p>
           <p>
            What Stark has done is easy. It may be ballsy but it was easy and proves nothing other than that he prefers attention over challenge and stupidity over careful thought.
           </p>
           <p>
            My kids are big fans of Nickelodeon's

             Dora The Explorer
            </em>
            . Mr. Stark, you could take some advice from Dora when she says:

            </p>

         <li id="c1467">

            </a>

             Shame, yep
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">

             <a href="/comments/364689/12794081#c1467?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1467">

            </p>
            <p>
             But don't forget: this is a person, yes, who has an
             <strong>
              extreme shame deficit.
             </strong>
             Billo has no trouble dishing out the shame, as he sees it. I really wonder what happens when his own sins are recounted to his face.
            </p>
            <p>

           <div class="ct">

          <li id="c1528">
           <div class="cx" id="cx12799288">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              A rose is a rose
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/364689/12799288#c1528?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1528">
               1+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:16704">
                expatjourno
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              A concern troll is a concern troll. There are people who disagree, have made their point and have moved on, and that's cool. They could be progressive, regressive, passive, liberals, conservative, whatever. I have no problem with that. Than there are people who are aggressively challenging anyone who finds Mr. Stark's actions less than reprehensible with name calling, and attacks on character intelligence and whatnot. Perhaps you've read them? In other words, they are acting like trolls.
             </p>
             <p>
              You behave like a troll, you're a troll.
             </p>
             <p>
              I don't care what you're ideological stance is.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:129260">
               Rappaccini
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/364689/12799288#c1528">
               Wed Aug 01, 2007 at 07:30:48 AM PDT
              </a>
             </p>
             <p class="cl">

              <a href="#c1475">

              </a>
              ]
             </p>

        <li id="c1480">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12796229">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            It's a guilty pleasure
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12796229#c1480?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1480">
             0+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            O'Reilly has been attacking and smearing KOS for a while now and I would argue that it has even moved into slander territory. He definitely had this coming. Fire with fire and all that.
           </p>
           <p>
            I only regret that KOS will now be in a position where it is living up to his claims that authors here are haters and nothing is beneith them. He is a savvy media figure. Passing out his embarrassing court materials to his neighbors is harsh, fitting in light of his tactics, but harsh. It opens up a martyr angle for him.
           </p>
           <p>
            It's too bad, in some ways, that hanging him with his own material isn't enough. He's got plenty of material.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>
           <p class="cb">

            <a href="/user/uid:101886">
             Plisko

        <li id="c1484">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12796541">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Mike Stark doesn't have a problem.
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12796541#c1484?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1484">
             2+ / 0-
            </a>

           </span>

          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:630">
              claude
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:103732">
              Bronx59
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            It's the rest of us that do. How many of us Kossacks sit at our keyboards (like our right wing counterparts) commenting/ranting on this and that, but never, EVER do anything physical to protest reichwing propaganda monkeys like Bill O'Reilly?
           </p>
           <p>
            Of course, such confrontations are mostly in vain, because Billy isn't the source of the problem. For that you have to look at the wizards behind the curtain: Roger Ailes, Rupert Murdoch, Grover Norquist, Rove, Cheney, etc. (Where do they live, by the way?) O'Reilly and such are the picadors that distract the bull so the matadors can maneuver unhindered.
           </p>
           <p>
            What Stark is doing is a bit like sending in an opposing picador to bother the first picador. What might be more useful would be a movement to revoke Rupert Murdoch's American citizenship and have him deported back to Australia, minus any business holdings in the United States. Hasn't this foreigner interfered enough with America's internal politics?
           </p>
          </div>

            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              Frank, They already call us insane. They already call us radical.
              <br/>
              Do we cower and scramble to be good girls and boys so that they won't call us names? No. They are simply using this framing, regardless of what we do. The corporate media buys into it, it serves their purpose as well.
             </p>
             <p>
              So, we are left to create our own media - which is what Mike is doing.
             </p>
             <p>
              Why does O'Reilly think we are the like KKK? Where does that come from? Mike didn't have to do a dang thing and already we're like the Nazis.
             </p>
             <p>
              So, no. When you cast someone out of the tribe, you must be careful, because it also gives them incredible freedom. The Republicans decided we were no longer Americans. Ok, so now we act like Americans and enjoy our free speech.

         </div>

        <li id="c1551">
         <div class="cx" id="cx12802765">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Fight Fire with Fire
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/364689/12802765#c1551?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1551">
             1+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:103732">
              Bronx59
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            I agree that we as progressives need to maintain a higher standard than the regressives like O'Reilly, but to say that this was over the top is like admitting that we'll never say "enough is enough!". There are times and situations where reasoned dialogue are appropriate, and then there are fist fights where things get dirty and all rules are off. I think a lot of progressives think that life is inherently fair and that the good guys will always win in the end. Well, I've been waiting for the good guys to win since they started the Clinton impeachment hearings, and guess what... a lot of people are dead now because we sat on our asses waiting for the good guys to win.
           </p>
           <p>
            O'Reilly has been a lying, bullying, loud-mouthed, a$$hole (understatement of the century) for years, and it's affected our country in a very negative way. I look at O'Reilly and his ilk as homegrown terrorists who just happen to have access to mass media. I mean, just because you have a television show doesn't absolve you of being a threat to the "American way of life". I say that anything (non-violent and legal) that we can do to remind O'Reilly's "fans" of what this guy's really about, is a good thing.
           </p>
           <p>
            I think the reason progressives are so negatively perceived by those who don't watch politics closely, is because quite frankly, we don't do enough things like this. We keep saying that "...oh, just let the republicans do what they want and eventually the public will see how bad they are...", but as we've seen, even after thousands of dead soldiers, an Iraqi genocide, no weapons of mass destruction, and what will be a trillion dollar price tag, the American public WILL NOT PASSIVELY "GET IT"!!!!
           </p>
           <p>
            I commend Stark because atleast he's
            <strong>
             doing something
            </strong>
            besides complaining on a blog (no offense). THere was a time in this country where civil disobedience was not only accepted, it was EXpected! And let's not forget that WE (the progressives) ARE RIGHT!
           </p>
           <p>
            Bravo to Stark for having some balls.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>
           <p class="cb">
            by
            <a href="/user/uid:92633">
             josh1000f
            </a>
            on
            <a href="/comments/364689/12802765#c1551">
             Wed Aug 01, 2007 at 10:07:48 AM PDT
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="cl">
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </li>
        <ul class="cm i1" id="k12802765">
         <li id="c1563">
          <div class="cx" id="cx12811944">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             You're Dead On
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/364689/12811944#c1563?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1563">
              0+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             Devils like O'Reilly count on people who are content only to complain.
            </p>
            <p>
             Stark hit him with a glancing body shot and hopefully,he and others will continue to put his bizarre hypocrisies in his face.
            </p>
            <p>
             O'Reilly is a first class creep and needs to have his ass whipped both metaphorically and physically.
            </p>
           </div>

           </span>

            <a href="/comments/364689/12815144#c1565?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1565">
             0+ / 0-
            </a>

           </span>

            reading DailyKos for stuff like this.
            <br/>
            I I would like this kinda stuff, I would be over at O'Reillys page.
           </p>
           <p>
            I really liked the style till now. Reporting about the bullshit that guy talks and does in a more or less professional way filled my heart with joy.
           </p>

            I never cared much for BillO's
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">

            <a href="/comments/364689/12876742#c1575?mode=alone;showrate=1#c1575">

          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            politics or his thug like behavior, but I didn't waste time or energy hating him untill he endorsed an attack by terrorist scumbags on the city I grew up near, and have family members living in...            </p>
           <p>
            That man has abused his power and hurt alot of people in profound ways, this action of taking it to his neighborhood doesn't surprise me at all. You can be the schoolyard bully or the junk yard dog for only so long, untill a situation escalates.
           </p>
           <p>
            Before Fox news came along, this nation had it's dissagrements, but fox has given the most dspicable people a microphone to escalate disgreements into dangerous raw emotion that was bound to escalate ..
           </p>
           <p>
            It's sad that Murdoch allows this kind of crap on his network. And when BillO screamed at Dodd, that was just way over the top.

          </a>
         </div>

   $(document).ready( App.initOnReady );
	
        kos.story_id = 364689;
        kos.sid = '2007/7/31/9920/91146';
		//kos.LAST_SEEN = '0';
		kos.LAST_SEEN = DailyKos.CommentCount.getReadCommentCount(kos.story_id);
		kos.pub_status = 'published';
		kos.version = 0;
		kos.trcount = 0;
		kos.trremain = 0;
		kos.serial = 1577;
		kos.updated = '2015-04-11 16:16:33';
		kos.hidingchoice = false;
		kos.can_comment = 0;

		jQuery(function() {
			jQuery('li.from-mobile .cx').each(function() {
				var counts				= jQuery(this).find('.crd.ntb').clone(true),
						dropTriangle 	= jQuery(this).find('.de').clone(true);

				jQuery(this).find('h5').hide();
				jQuery(this).find('.ct').prepend(dropTriangle);
				jQuery(this).find('.ct').prepend(counts);
				jQuery(this).find('.ct::first-line').css('background', 'red')	});
		});

			autoOpen: false,
			width: 600,
			position: 'center',

    e.setAttribute('language', 'javascript');

       "js/chartbeat.js");

  <script type="text/javascript">
   DailyKos.Metrics.metricsOn = (0 === 1);
	  DailyKos.Metrics.sampleSize = 20;
		DailyKos.Metrics.setUserProperties({
			requestFormat: 'full site',
			subscriber: false,
			mobile: $.browser.mobile,
			loggedIn: false,
			staff: false
		});
		DailyKos.Metrics.init();
  </script>
  <script type="text/javascript">
   if (document.location.pathname.match(/^\/story/)) {
			  DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Story', {  url: "http://www.dailykos.com/story/2007/07/31/364689/-I-just-returned-from-Falafel-Bill-s-house", 
			                                            blog: "Mike Stark",
			                                            author: $('.author').children('a').first().html(),
			                                            title: $('#titleHref').html()
			                                          });
			} else if (document.location.pathname.match(/^\/comment/)) {
			  DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Comment');
			}
  </script>
  <script type="text/javascript">
   if($.cookie('meter_user') !== 'false') {
		if ($('#ePostButton').length &gt; 0) {
		  $('#ePostButton').click(function() { 
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Posted Comment', { 
		      repliedTo: $(this).parents('#eP').prevAll('.cb').children('a').first().html() 
		    });
		  });
		}
		
		if (!!document.location.pathname.match('activate') &amp;&amp; $('h1:contains("Welcome to Daily Kos!")').length &gt; 0) {
		  DailyKos.Metrics.track('Signed Up');
		}
		
		if (document.location.pathname === '/') {
		  if (document.location.hostname.match(/^www|^dailykos/)) {
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Front Page');
		  } else {
		    var subdomain = document.location.hostname.split('.')[0];
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Vertical', { name: subdomain });
		  }
		}
		
		if ($('.ratinate').length &gt; 0) {
		  $('.ratinate').click(function() { DailyKos.Metrics.track('Recommended Comment') });
		}
		
		if ($('.do-addRating.type-story').length &gt; 0) {
		  $('.do-addRating.type-story').click(function() { DailyKos.Metrics.track('Recommended Story') });
		}
		
		if ($("form[action$='publishHow']").length &gt; 0) {
		  $(document).ready(function() {
			  $('.type-story.do-publishHow').click(function() { DailyKos.Metrics.track('Published Story') });
			 });
		}
		
		if (document.location.pathname.match(/^\/user/) &amp;&amp; $('li.here').length &gt; 0) {
		  if ($('.pageMenu:first li.here').children('a').html().match(/Stream/)) {
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Stream', { name: $('.name').children('a').html() });
		  } else if ($('.pageMenu:first li.here').children('a').html().match(/Profile/)) {
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Profile', { name: $('.name').children('a').html() });
		  } else if ($('.pageMenu:last li.here').children('a').html().match(/My Recent Replies/)) {
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Replies');
		  }
		} 
		
		if ($('#search-tabbed').length &gt; 0) {
		  DailyKos.Metrics.track('Searched');
		}
		
		if ($('#group-tables').length &gt; 0) {
			DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Groups List');
		}
		
		if (document.location.pathname.match(/^\/groups/) &amp;&amp; $("#group_info").length &gt; 0) {
		  DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Group', { name: $('.name').children('a').text() });
		}
		
		if ($('.do-hotlist.type-user, .do-unHotlist.type-user').length &gt; 0) {
		  $('.do-hotlist.type-user, .do-unHotlist.type-user').click(function() {
		    var nickName;
		    nickName = ($(this).prev('a').html() || $('.name a').html())
		    if ($(this).hasClass('do-hotlist')) {
		      DailyKos.Metrics.track('Followed User', { nickname: nickName }) 
		    } else if ($(this).hasClass('do-unHotlist')) {
		      DailyKos.Metrics.track('Unfollowed User', { nickname: nickName }) 
		    }    
		  });
		}
	}
  </script>
